'''Jean-François Papillon''' (died in the early 1800s) was one of the principal leaders in the [[Haitian Revolution]] against slavery and French rule. He led the initial uprising of enslaved workers and later allied with Spain against the French.
He was born in Africa but [[slavery|enslaved]] and taken in captivity to the North Province of [[Saint-Domingue]] (the future nation of [[Haiti]]). There he worked in the plantation of Papillon in the last decades of the 18th Century. He escaped from that plantation and became a [[Maroon (people)|maroon]], so when the revolution started in August 1791 he had already enjoyed a direct experience of freedom.<ref>{{cite book|last=Saint-Rémy|first=Joseph|title=Mémoires du général Toussaint L'Ouverture, écrits par lui même|year=1850|pages=22}}</ref>
== Ascent to power ==
Right after the tragic death of [[Dutty Boukman|Boukman Dutty]], the insurgent slaves’ first leader, Jean-François Papillon imposed his authority over the other black generals, especially [[Georges Biassou]], Jeannot Bullet and Toussaint Bréda (later [[Toussaint Louverture]]), and became commander-in-chief of the Haitian former slaves. By late 1791, some weeks after the revolutionary outbreak, Jean-François and Biassou set their rivalry aside in order to oppose Jeannot, who not only massacred the French but also all the black soldiers that contested his authority. For that reason, Biassou and Jean-François arrested and executed him by November 1791.<ref>{{cite book|last=Dalmas|first=M.|title=Histoire de la Révolution de Saint-Domingue, depuis le commencement des troubles, jusqu'à la prise de Jérémie et du Mole S. Nicolas par les anglais; suivie d'un mémoire sur le rétablissement de cette colonie, vol. I|year=1814|publisher=Chez Mame Frères, Imprimeurs-Libraires, Rue du Pot-de-Fer, n. 14|location=Paris|pages=145–148}}</ref><ref>{{cite book|last=Lacroix|first=Pamphile de|title=Mémoires pour servir à l'histoire de la révolution de Saint-Domingue. Avec une carte nouvelle de l'île et un plan topographique de la Crête-à-Pierrot, tome premier|year=1819|publisher=Chez Pillet Ainé, Imprimeur-Libraire, Éditeur de la collection des moeurs françaises, Rue Christine, n. 5|location=Paris|pages=113–114.}}</ref><ref>{{cite book|last=Dubois|first=Laurent|title=Avengers of the New World: the Story of the Haitian Revolution|year=2004|publisher=Harvard University Press|location=Cambridge - Massachusetts|pages=122–123.}}</ref> It has often been assumed that Jean-François and his men rose up in rebellion to win universal freedom, but their real intention was to gain as much power as possible and return the rest of the slaves to the plantations when the revolution was over and the generals had already achieved power. Jean-François confessed his convictions to the North American agents in Le [[Cap-Haïtien|Cap Français]]: “[...] that General told us that he had not created himself General of the negroes, that those who had that power had confered [sic] upon him that title; that in taking up arms, he never pretended to fight for General Liberty, which he knew to be an illusion”.<ref>{{cite book|title=National Archives and Record Administration (NARA), Record Group (RG) 59, M 9, Dispatches from the United States Consuls in Cap Haïtien, 1797-1906, Roll (R.) 1/1797-1799, "Observations on the French Part of Hispaniola and the West India Islands worth perhaps to be noticed by the Government of the United States of America"|year=1797|location=[Le Cap]|pages=2}}</ref>
== Relation with Spain ==
There are many chances that the Spaniards backed the Haitian revolution from the beginning, providing the insurgents with food and weapons: they knew that the episode would cause chaos in Saint-Domingue, giving Spain the chance to send troops to that territory and re-annex it, since it had been a Spanish possession taken by the French in the [[Treaty of Ryswick|Peace Treaty of Ryswick]] (1697). In October 1791, the black General Toussaint Bréda admitted his contacts with the Spaniards, who had promised them provisions. As Spain was officially neutral towards the [[French revolution]], of which Saint-Domingue’s revolution was regarded as a mere echo, it kept its contacts with the black leaders in secret.
Spain’s attitude changed from late January 1793, when the [[National Convention|French National Convention]] executed [[Louis XVI of France|Louis XVI]]. From then on, the Spanish government considered that it was unnecessary to stay officially neutral towards France and both countries declared war on each other in March 1793. As a consequence, [[Charles IV of Spain]] issued his instructions to the Dominican authorities, which needed to begin official dealings with Saint-Domingue’s black generals to persuade them to join the Dominican army.<ref>{{cite book|title=Archivo General de Simancas (AGS), Secretaría del Despacho de Guerra (SGU), box (b.) 7157, expedient (e.) 22, document (d.) 343. The Dominican Archbishop describes his plan to negotiate with Jean-François, mentioning the King's instructions of February 22nd, 1793.|date=April 24, 1793|location=Santo Domingo}}</ref><ref>{{cite book|last=Deivw|first=Carlos Esteban|title=Los refugiados franceses en Santo Domingo, 1789-1801|year=1984|publisher=Universidad Nacional Pedro Henríquez Ureña|location=Santo Domingo|pages=101}}</ref><ref>{{cite book|last=Yacou|first=Alain|title=La stratégie espagnole d'éradication de Saint-Domingue français (1790-1804), in Saint-Domingue espagnol et la révolution nègre d'Haïti. Commémoration du Bicentenaire de la naissance de l'état d'Haïti (1804-2004), dir. Alain Yacou|year=2007|publisher=Karthala - CERC|location=Paris - Point-à-Pitre|pages=182}}</ref>
Negotiations, which were carried out by the mulatto priest José Vázquez, finished on May 6, 1793 with Jean-François’ oath of loyalty to the Spanish King in his name and in the name of his soldiers. The said oath was confirmed by Jean-François some days later, in an official letter addressed to the Dominican Archbishop, [[Fernando del Portillo y Torres]]. Nevertheless, the slave leaders made it clear that they did not support the Spanish King as an end in itself, but as a means of avenging the French King, the Spanish sovereign’s cousin.<ref>{{cite book|title=AGS, SGU, b. 7157, e. 22, d. 368. Jean-François' letter to the Dominican Archbishop, transmitting his oath of loyalty to the Spanish Crown|date=May 28, 1793|location=La Mine}}</ref>
== Triumphs and problems at the service of Spain ==
Jean-François and his collaborators became [[Charles IV of Spain|Carlos IV]]’s black auxiliary troops, since the colour of their skin prevented the Spaniards from considering them part of the colonial regular army. Their alliance to Spain was crucial for the Spanish army to make important progress in Hispaniola against the French, conquering important positions like [[Gonaïves]], [[Gros-Morne, Haiti|Gros-Morne]], [[Plaisance, Nord|Plaisance]], Acul, [[Limbé, Nord|Limbé]], [[Port-Margot]], [[Borgne]], Petit-Saint-Louis and [[Terre-Neuve, Artibonite|Terre-Neuve]].<ref>{{cite book|last=Ardouin|first=Beaubrun|title=Études sur l'histoire d'Haïti, vol. II|year=1853|publisher=Dezobry et E. Magdeleine, Lib. Éditeurs, Rue des Maçons-Sorbonne|location=Paris|pages=328–329}}</ref>
Nevertheless, there had always existed a strong tension between Jean-François and Biassou that led to an armed confrontation in September 1793. Both generals confronted each other and the French took advantage of the instability within the black auxiliaries to re-conquer the Tannerie fort, recently occupied by Jean-François’ troops. That episode convinced the Dominican government of the necessity to put an end to the internal tension of the black army, which was achieved thanks to the intervention of the Dominican Brigadier [[Matías de Armona]], who persuaded them to meet in [[Dondon]] and come to an agreement by late November 1793.<ref>{{cite book|title=AGS, SGU, b. 7157, e. 22, d. 466. Jean-François' letter to José Vázquez, telling him about the agreement with Biassou|date=November 17, 1793|location=Dondon}}</ref>
In the following weeks, the black auxiliaries achieved many other victories at the service of Spain, especially the conquest of Port Margot at the beginning in 1794, which earned them several golden and silver medals given by the Spanish Crown.<ref>{{cite book|last=Victoria Ojeda|first=Jorge|title=De "libertad, excepciones, goces y prerrogativas". Impulso y dispersión de las tropas auxiliares del rey de España en la guerra de Santo Domingo (1793-1848). Tesis doctoral dirigida por el doctor José Antonio Piqueras, leída en la Facultad de Ciencias Humanas y Sociales|year=2005|publisher=Universitat Jaume I|location=Castellón de la Plana|pages=60–61, 67}}</ref>
== Bayajá ==
The prestige of the black auxiliaries started to decay in July 1794, after the massacre of Bayajá. This place had been a French possession ([[Fort-Liberté|Fort Dauphin]]) until the Spaniards conquered it in January 1794. At that moment, the authorities of the village asked the Spaniards to not let Jean-François’ troops enter the place in the future, because they were afraid that the latter would massacre them, provided that most of its inhabitants were the former owners of Jean-François’ collaborators, and also that one of the officers that surrendered the city to Spain was the mulato Candy, Jean-François’ former subordinate that had deserted to the French camp.<ref>{{cite book|last=Ardouin|first=Beaubrun|title=Études sur l'histoire d'Haïti, vol. II|year=1853|publisher=Dezobry et E. Magdeleine, Lib. Éditeurs, Rue des Maçons-Sorbonne|location=Paris|pages=410}}</ref>
Despite the described circumstances, on July 7, 1794 Jean-François entered the place with his troops and massacred the French inhabitants, mostly, though many Spaniards died also in the episode. The Spanish garrison of the place did not interfere to stop the killing, for which they were criticised by other foreign governments that even accused Spain of supporting the killing from the shadow.
From that moment on, not only did the Spaniards realise that the black auxiliaries were dangerous, but they also prevented them from taking part in any other important campaign in the future, so that such abuses would not occur again.<ref>{{cite book|last=Geggus|first=David|title=Haitian Revolutionary Studies|year=2002|publisher=Indiana University Press|location=Bloomington & Indianapolis|pages=176}}</ref>
== Basel and the diaspora of the auxiliaries ==
The Spaniards’ awareness of the black auxiliaries’ “natural savagery” as well as Santo Domingo’s cession to France in the [[Peace of Basel|Peace Treaty of Basel]], persuaded them to get rid of Jean-François and his troops, since the circumstances that had justified their alliance to the former slaves, that is, Spain’s plan to conquer the western part of Hispaniola, had failed.
First, Jean-François and his main collaborators were taken to [[Havana]]. But the Cuban governor, [[Luis de las Casas]], was so afraid that their presence there would provoke a massive black insurrection in that island, that he pressured the Spanish government to throw them out of his colony.<ref>{{cite book|title=Archivo General de Indias (AGI), Estado (E.), e. 24, d. 1. Luis de las Casas' report about the arrival of Jean-François|date=January 8, 1796|location=La Habana}}</ref><ref>{{cite book|last=Geggus|first=David|title=Haitian Revolutionary Studies|year=2002|publisher=Indiana University Press|location=Bloomington & Indianapolis|pages=183–184}}</ref>
In March 1796 they arrived to the Spanish city of [[Cadiz|Cádiz]], where they were kept almost as prisoners. Their situation in that city was dramatic: the generals lost their military ranks and their right to any economic compensation after their retirement and, in addition, Jean-François had to use the few resources he had to assist his family and his companions.<ref>{{cite book|last=Geggus|first=David|title=Haitian Revolutionary Studies|year=2002|publisher=Indiana University Press|location=Bloomington & Indianapolis|pages=198}}</ref>
In 1813, the Spanish Council of Regency decided to throw them out of that city and take them to the Coast of the Flies. Unfortunately, Jean-François never saw the resolution of the conflict that concerned his troops, as he had already died in the early days of the 19th Century, maybe in 1805, totally forgotten by the Spanish government, which “rewarded” him for his loyal services by denying any official link with him or any other slave general in the past.<ref>{{cite book|last=Victoria Ojeda|first=Jorge|title=De "libertad, excepciones, goces y prerrogativas". Impulso y dispersión de las tropas auxiliares del rey de España en la guerra de Santo Domingo (1793-1848). Tesis doctoral dirigida por el doctor José Antonio Piqueras, leída en la Facultad de Ciencias Humanas y Sociales|year=2005|publisher=Universita Jaume I|location=Castellón de la Plana|pages=154, 162}}</ref>

{{Use British English|date=July 2014}} {{Use dmy dates|date=February 2018}} [[File:Jimmy Savile PICT6249a gaussian blur.jpg|thumb|right|upright|Savile in July 2006, attending the [[Highland games]] in [[Lochaber]]]] '''[[Jimmy Savile]]''' (1926–2011) was an English media personality who was well known in the United Kingdom for his eccentricities and, at the time of his death, was generally respected for his charitable work. He was [[knighthood|knighted]] in 1990. In late 2012, almost a year after his death, reports surfaced indicating that Savile had committed [[sexual abuse]] throughout his 50-year career, his alleged victims ranging from [[Puberty|prepubescent]] girls and boys to adults. By 11 October 2012, allegations had been made to thirteen British [[List of police forces of the United Kingdom|police forces]],{{cite news |first=Martin |last=Evans |url= https://www.telegraph.co.uk/news/uknews/crime/9601922/Sir-Jimmy-Savile-fourth-British-TV-personality-accused-in-sex-allegations.html |title=Sir Jimmy Savile: fourth British TV personality accused in sex allegations |newspaper=[[The Daily Telegraph]] |location =London |date=11 October 2012 |accessdate=11 October 2012}} which led to the setting-up of inquiries into practices at the [[BBC]] and within the [[National Health Service (England)|National Health Service]]. On 19 October 2012, [[London]]'s [[Metropolitan Police Service]] launched a formal criminal investigation, [[Operation Yewtree]], into historic allegations of [[child sexual abuse]] by Savile and other individuals, some still living, over four decades. The Metropolitan Police stated that it was pursuing over 400 lines of inquiry, based on the claims of 200 witnesses, via fourteen police forces across the UK. It described the alleged abuse as being "on an unprecedented scale", and the number of potential victims as "staggering".{{cite news |url= https://www.bbc.co.uk/news/uk-20006049 |title=Savile abuse claims: Met Police launch criminal inquiry |publisher=BBC News |date=19 October 2012 |accessdate=19 October 2012}}{{cite news |url= https://www.telegraph.co.uk/news/uknews/crime/jimmy-savile/9620149/Jimmy-Savile-police-launch-criminal-investigation-after-victims-claim-some-abusers-are-still-alive.html |title=Jimmy Savile: police launch criminal investigation after victims claim some abusers are still alive |work=The Daily Telegraph |location =London |date=19 October 2012 |accessdate=19 October 2012}} By 19 December, eight people had been questioned as part of the investigation. The Met stated that the total number of alleged victims was 589, of whom 450 alleged abuse by Savile.{{cite news |url= https://www.bbc.co.uk/news/uk-20686219 |publisher= BBC News |title= Savile abuse part of Operation Yewtree probe 'complete' |date= 11 December 2012 |accessdate= 11 December 2012 }}{{cite news |url= https://www.bbc.co.uk/news/uk-20697738 |publisher= BBC News |title= Jimmy Savile abuse: Number of alleged victims reaches 450 |date=12 December 2012 |accessdate=12 December 2012}} The report of the investigations undertaken jointly by the police and the [[National Society for the Prevention of Cruelty to Children]] (NSPCC), ''[[Giving Victims a Voice]]'', was published on 11 January 2013. It reported allegations covering a period of 50 years, including 214 alleged acts by Savile which, though uncorroborated, have been formally recorded as crimes, some involving children as young as eight. The report states "within the recorded crimes there are 126 indecent acts and 34 [[sex offence|rape/penetration offences]]." Alleged offences took place at thirteen hospitals as well as on BBC premises, according to the report.{{cite web |url= http://www.nspcc.org.uk/news-and-views/our-news/child-protection-news/13-01-11-yewtree-report/yewtree-report-pdf_wdf93652.pdf |title=Giving Victims a Voice |publisher=Crown Prosecution Service |date=January 2013}}{{cite news |url= https://www.bbc.co.uk/news/uk-20981611 |publisher= BBC News |title= Jimmy Savile scandal: Report reveals extent of abuse |date=11 January 2013 |accessdate=11 January 2013 }} In October 2013 it was announced that inquiries had been extended to other hospitals.{{cite news |url= https://www.bbc.co.uk/news/uk-24520001 |publisher= BBC News |title= NHS Savile abuse probe widened|date=14 October 2013 |accessdate=14 October 2013 }} On 26 June 2014, the [[Secretary of State for Health]], [[Jeremy Hunt (politician)|Jeremy Hunt]], reported on the findings of the investigations led by [[Kate Lampard]]. He said that Savile had sexually assaulted victims aged between 5 and 75 in NHS hospitals, and he apologised to the victims.{{cite news |url= https://www.bbc.com/news/uk-28034427 |publisher= BBC News |title= Jimmy Savile NHS abuse victims aged five to 75 |date=26 June 2014 |accessdate=30 June 2014 }} Further investigations, in hospitals and elsewhere, led to additional allegations of sexual abuse by Savile. Much of Savile's career involved working with children and young people, including visiting schools and hospital wards. He spent 20 years presenting ''[[Top of the Pops]]'' before a teenage audience, and an overlapping 20 years presenting ''[[Jim'll Fix It]]'', in which he helped the wishes of viewers, mainly children, come true. During his lifetime, two police investigations had looked into reports about Savile, the earliest known being in 1958, but none had led to charges; the reports had each concluded that there was insufficient evidence for any charges to be brought related to sexual offences.{{cite news |url= https://www.bbc.co.uk/news/world-europe-jersey-19802630 |title=Jimmy Savile named in Jersey children's home abuse inquiry |publisher= BBC News |date=2 October 2012 |accessdate=2 October 2012}}{{cite news |first1=Sam |last1=Marsden |first2=Richard |last2=Alleyne |url= https://www.telegraph.co.uk/news/uknews/9578870/Jimmy-Savile-interviewed-under-caution-over-indecent-assault-allegation.html |title=Jimmy Savile interviewed under caution over indecent assault allegation |work=The Daily Telegraph |location =London |date=1 October 2012 |accessdate=1 October 2012}}{{cite web|last=Mendick |first=Robert |url=https://www.telegraph.co.uk/news/uknews/crime/jimmy-savile/9606494/Jimmy-Savile-police-officers-repeatedly-failed-sex-victims.html |title=Jimmy Savile: police officers repeatedly failed sex victims |newspaper=The Daily Telegraph |location= London |date=13 October 2012 |accessdate=7 March 2017}} In October 2012 it was announced that the [[Director of Public Prosecutions]], [[Keir Starmer]], would investigate why proceedings against Savile in 2009 were dropped. The scandal was a major factor leading to the establishment of the wider-ranging [[Independent Inquiry into Child Sexual Abuse]] which was announced by then-[[Home Secretary]] [[Theresa May]] in July 2014. In February 2015, the inquiry was reconfigured as a [[statutory inquiry]] to be chaired by [[Judge|Justice]] [[Lowell Goddard]]. ==Background== [[Jimmy Savile]] claimed the key to his success on ''[[Jim'll Fix It]]'' had been that he disliked children, although he later admitted to saying it to deflect scrutiny of his private life. He did not own a computer as, he claimed, he did not want people to think he was downloading [[child pornography]].{{cite news |url= https://www.telegraph.co.uk/news/obituaries/8857428/Sir-Jimmy-Savile.html |title=Sir Jimmy Savile |newspaper=The Daily Telegraph |location= London |date=29 October 2011 |accessdate=7 March 2017}} In a 1990 interview for ''[[The Independent on Sunday]]'', [[Lynn Barber]] asked him about rumours that he liked "little girls". Savile said:
"...the young girls in question don't gather round me because of me – it's because I know the people they love, the stars... I am of no interest to them."{{cite news |url= https://www.independent.co.uk/arts-entertainment/tv/features/lynn-barber-i-was-nervous-when-i-told-jimmy-savile-people-say-you-like-little-girls-8193169.html |title=Lynn Barber: I was nervous when I told Jimmy Savile, 'People say you like little girls' |first=Lynn |last= Barber| work= Independent on Sunday |location =London |date=2 October 2012 |accessdate=5 November 2012}}
In April 2000, Savile was the subject of an in-depth documentary{{cite news |url= https://www.theguardian.com/theobserver/2014/mar/23/louis-theroux-inhabit-intimate-space-jimmy-savile |title=Louis Theroux: 'You get to inhabit quite an intimate space' |newspaper=The Guardian |date=22 March 2014 |accessdate=20 March 2015 |last=Lewis |first=Tim}} by [[Louis Theroux]], in the ''[[When Louis Met...]]'' series. In it, Theroux asked about rumours he was a [[pedophilia|paedophile]].{{cite news |first= Jonathan |last=Jones |url= https://www.theguardian.com/commentisfree/2012/oct/04/jimmy-savile-hiding-in-the-light |title= Jimmy Savile was hiding in the light |newspaper=The Guardian |date=4 October 2012 |accessdate=11 October 2012 |location =London}} Savile said:{{cite news |url= http://www.newstatesman.com/blogs/culture/2012/10/when-louis-asked-jimmy-about-being-paedophile |title=When Louis asked Jimmy about being a paedophile |first=Alex |last=Hern| newspaper=[[New Statesman]] |location =London |date=3 October 2012 |accessdate=17 October 2012}}
"[We] live in a very funny world. And it's easier for me, as a single man, to say "I don't like children" because that puts a lot of salacious tabloid people off the hunt.... How do they know whether I am [a paedophile] or not? How does anybody know whether I am? Nobody knows whether I am or not. I know I'm not."
A follow-up documentary, ''[[Louis Theroux's BBC Two specials|Louis Theroux: Savile]]'',{{cite news |first=Jasper |last=Rees |url= https://www.telegraph.co.uk/tv/2016/10/02/louis-theroux-savile--how-the-broadcaster-duped-the-documentary/ |title=Louis Theroux: Savile – how the broadcaster duped the documentary maker: review |newspaper=The Daily Telegraph |date=3 October 2016 |accessdate=7 March 2017}}{{cite web|url=http://www.theartsdesk.com/tv/louis-theroux-savile-bbc-two |title=Louis Theroux: Savile, BBC Two |publisher=The Arts Desk |date=3 October 2016 |accessdate=7 March 2017}}{{cite news |url= https://www.theguardian.com/film/2016/oct/02/louis-theroux-i-have-a-slight-fear-of-intimacy |title=Louis Theroux: 'I have a slight fear of intimacy' | Film |newspaper=The Guardian |location= London |date=2 October 2016 |accessdate=7 March 2017}}{{cite web|author=Lawrence Arboleda |url=http://www.inquisitr.com/3557423/shocking-footage-of-jimmy-savile-groping-a-girl-in-front-of-her-mother-caught-for-bbc-documentary/ |title=Jimmy Savile Caught Groping A Girl In Front Of Her Mother In New Louis Theroux Footage |publisher=Inquisitr.com |date=2 October 2016 |accessdate=7 March 2017}} about Theroux's inability to detect Savile's true nature,{{cite news |url= https://www.bbc.co.uk/news/entertainment-arts-34709583.stm |title=Louis Theroux to make new Jimmy Savile film |publisher=BBC News |date=3 November 2015 |accessdate=6 March 2016}} aired on [[BBC Two]] in 2016.{{cite web|url=http://www.bbc.co.uk/programmes/b07yc9zh |title=BBC TWO Louis Theroux: Savile |publisher=BBC |date= |accessdate=3 October 2016}} Broadcaster and journalist Orla Barry, on the Irish radio station [[Newstalk]] in 2007, asked Savile about allegations aired during the original Theroux documentary. When asked about the paedophilia rumours, Savile responded, "What rumours?".{{Citation needed|date=March 2017}} In 2012, Barry expressed surprise that other journalists had not pursued the matter, saying, "Maybe in the UK they were slightly closer to him."{{cite news |first=Niamh |last=Horan |url= http://www.independent.ie/national-news/i-dont-know-why-nobody-took-him-on-sooner-barry-3258561.html |title=I don't know why nobody took him on sooner – Barry |newspaper=Sunday Independent |location =Dublin |date=14 October 2012 |accessdate=14 October 2012}} In 2007, Savile was interviewed [[Right to silence in England and Wales|under caution]] by police investigating an allegation of indecent assault at the now-closed [[Approved School|Duncroft Approved School for Girls]] near [[Staines]], [[Surrey]] in the 1970s, when he was a regular visitor. The [[Crown Prosecution Service]] (CPS) advised there was insufficient evidence to take any further action and no charges were brought. In 2012 it was reported that staff at the school had not been questioned about the allegations at the time.{{cite news |url= https://www.bbc.co.uk/news/uk-20147834 |title=Jimmy Savile scandal: Police did not question Duncroft staff |publisher=BBC News |date= 30 October 2012 |accessdate=7 March 2017}} A former [[headmaster|headmistress]] of the school said she had been "hoodwinked" by Savile,{{cite news |url= http://www.walesonline.co.uk/news/wales-news/2012/11/03/former-head-of-duncroft-approved-school-admits-she-was-hoodwinked-by-jimmy-savile-91466-32159321/ |work=Wales Online |title=Former head of Duncroft admits she was 'hoodwinked' by Jimmy Savile |date=3 November 2012 |accessdate=17 November 2012}} but described some of those who had brought the allegations as "delinquents".{{cite news |url= http://www.itv.com/news/update/2012-11-03/headteacher-savile-abuse-girls-looking-for-money/ |title=Savile abuse girls 'looking for money' - headteacher |publisher=ITV News |date=3 November 2012 |accessdate=7 March 2017}}{{cite news |first1=Sarah |last1=Lyall |first2=Lark |last2=Turner |url= https://www.nytimes.com/2012/11/11/world/europe/long-ago-jimmy-savile-abuse-complaint-is-heeded.html |title=Jimmy Savile Molested Me: Charge Finally Listened To |newspaper=The New York Times |date=10 November 2012 |accessdate=7 March 2017}} In March 2008, Savile started legal proceedings against ''[[The Sun (United Kingdom)|The Sun]]'' newspaper, which had linked him in several articles to child abuse at the [[Jersey]] children's home [[Jersey child abuse investigation 2008|Haut de la Garenne]].{{cite news |url= http://www.thelawyer.com/jimmy-savile-turns-to-fox-hayes-for-action-against-the-sun/131780.article |title= Jimmy Savile turns to Fox Hayes for action against The Sun |work=The Lawyer |author= Goswami, Nina |location =London |date=17 March 2008 |accessdate=1 October 2012}} Savile denied visiting Haut de la Garenne, but admitted doing so after a photograph was published showing him at the home surrounded by children.{{cite news |first= Richard |last=Alleyne |url= https://www.telegraph.co.uk/news/uknews/crime/9583373/Sir-Jimmy-Savile-He-raped-me-as-a-teenager-claims-woman.html |title=Sir Jimmy Savile: He raped me as a teenager claims woman |newspaper=The Daily Telegraph |location =London |date=3 October 2012|accessdate=3 October 2012}} The [[States of Jersey Police]] said an allegation of indecent assault by Savile at the home in the 1970s had been investigated in 2008, but there had been insufficient evidence to proceed.{{cite news |url= https://www.bbc.co.uk/news/world-europe-jersey-19802630 |title= Jimmy Savile named in Jersey children's home abuse inquiry |publisher=BBC News |date=2 October 2012 |accessdate=2 October 2012}} ==Journalism== ===Aborted ''Newsnight'' report=== Savile died on 29 October 2011, aged 84. At the time of his death and the funeral in [[Leeds Cathedral]], he was widely praised for his charity and voluntary activities as well as his entertainment work.{{cite news |url= https://www.bbc.co.uk/news/entertainment-arts-15507374 |title=DJ and TV presenter Jimmy Savile dies, aged 84 |publisher=BBC News |date=29 October 2011 |accessdate=16 October 2012}}{{cite news |url= https://www.bbc.co.uk/news/uk-england-leeds-15647363 |title=Sir Jimmy Savile's funeral takes place at Leeds Cathedral |publisher=BBC News |date=9 November 2011 |accessdate=16 October 2012}} Immediately after Savile's death, [[Meirion Jones]] and [[Liz Mackean]] from the [[BBC]] programme ''[[Newsnight]]'' began to investigate reports that he had sexually abused children. They interviewed one alleged victim on camera and talked to a number of others who were willing to be quoted about alleged abuse at Duncroft Approved School, the BBC, and [[Stoke Mandeville Hospital]]. The former headmistress of Duncroft was Jones' own aunt.{{cite web|url=https://www.telegraph.co.uk/news/uknews/crime/jimmy-savile/9623803/Jimmy-Savile-Newsnight-producer-is-nephew-of-abuse-school-headmistress.html|title=Jimmy Savile: Newsnight producer is nephew of abuse school headmistress |date=21 October 2012|work=The Telegraph}} The ''Newsnight'' team, which included former police detective [[Mark Williams-Thomas]], also found out about a 2009 [[Surrey Police]] investigation into Savile. The report was scheduled for broadcast on 7 December 2011, but a decision was taken to cancel its transmission, which ultimately developed into a major crisis for the BBC when the allegations against Savile were made public in October 2012. The subsequent [[Nick Pollard|Pollard Review]] found that Jones and MacKean had assembled cogent evidence that Savile had a history of abusing young women and ''Newsnight'' had been in a position to break the story in 2011.{{cite news|title=BBC releases Pollard report into axed Jimmy Savile Newsnight investigation|url=https://www.theguardian.com/media/2012/dec/19/bbc-report-jimmy-savile-newsnight|newspaper=The Guardian|date=19 December 2012}} In January 2012, the ''[[Sunday Mirror]]'' reported that ''Newsnight'' had investigated allegations of sexual abuse immediately after Savile's death but that the report had been shelved.{{cite news|title=Jimmy Savile: timeline of his sexual abuse and its uncovering|url=https://www.theguardian.com/media/2014/jun/26/jimmy-savile-sexual-abuse-timeline|first=Josh|last=Halliday|newspaper=The Guardian|date=26 June 2014|accessdate=15 April 2018}} An article by [[Miles Goslett]] in the March 2012 edition of ''[[The Oldie]]'' alleged a cover-up.{{cite news|title=The Oldie scoop that exposed Jimmy Savile|url=https://www.theoldie.co.uk/blog/savile-row-1|first=Miles|last=Goslett|newspaper=The Oldie|date=5 March 2018|accessdate=15 April 2018}} The BBC showed two Savile tributes over the 2011 [[Christmas]] period, and it was alleged that the ''Newsnight'' report had been dropped because its content would have compromised the showing of the tributes. A joint submission to the [[Leveson Inquiry#Witnesses|Leveson Inquiry]] from Anna van Heeswijk (Object), Jacqui Hunt ([[Equality Now]]), Heather Harvey (Eaves) and Marai Larasi ([[End Violence Against Women Coalition|End Violence against Women]]) was titled "Just the Women", a phrase which was reportedly written by ''Newsnight'' editor [[Peter Rippon]] in an email to a colleague concerning the lack of other authorities [than the alleged female victims] for evidence of Savile's abuse.{{cite web |url=http://www.endviolenceagainstwomen.org.uk/data/files/resources/51/Just-the-Women-Nov-2012.pdf |title=Just the Women |publisher=End Violence Against Women |date=24 November 2012 |accessdate=7 March 2017 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20160327055327/http://www.endviolenceagainstwomen.org.uk/data/files/resources/51/Just-the-Women-Nov-2012.pdf |archivedate=27 March 2016 |df=dmy-all }} A ''Newsnight'' spokesman said, "Any suggestion that a story was dropped for anything other than editorial reasons is completely untrue."{{cite news |url= https://www.telegraph.co.uk/culture/tvandradio/bbc/9073142/BBC-buried-Savile-sex-abuse-claims-to-save-its-reputation.html |author=Singh, Anita |title=BBC 'buried Savile sex abuse claims to save its reputation' |work=The Daily Telegraph |location =London |date=10 February 2012 |accessdate=20 November 2012}} In October 2013, the transcript of Surrey Police's interview with Savile in 2009 was published after a request under the [[Freedom of Information Act 2000|Freedom of information Act]]. Savile denied the sexual abuse allegations relating to Duncroft Approved School put to him by the police, saying, "I've never, ever done anything wrong" and stating that the accusers wanted a "few quid".{{cite news |author=Quinn, Ben |url=https://www.theguardian.com/media/2013/oct/15/jimmy-savile-boasted-police-abuse |newspaper=The Guardian |location =London |title=Jimmy Savile boasted to police of his 'policy' he used to halt abuse claims |date=15 October 2013 |accessdate=16 October 2013}}[https://web.archive.org/web/20131016220234/http://www.surrey.police.uk/tabid/2980/InfoItemId/197/Default.aspx ] ===''Exposure: The Other Side of Jimmy Savile''=== An [[ITV (TV network)|ITV]] documentary, ''[[Exposure (UK TV series)|Exposure: The Other Side of Jimmy Savile]]'', was broadcast on 3 October 2012. It was researched and presented by Mark Williams-Thomas, a former police investigator who had been involved in the shelved ''Newsnight'' investigation. Several women interviewed by ''Exposure'' said that, as teenagers, they had been sexually abused by Savile. It was also said Savile obtained access to teenage girls through his television programmes ''Top of the Pops'' and ''Clunk, Click'' (1973–74), and his charity work. Savile's former colleagues said he made no attempt to hide his interest in girls from them, while another said she had walked in on him [[french kiss]]ing an underage girl.{{Citation needed|date=March 2017}} One woman who said Savile had sexually assaulted her in 1970, when she was 14, explained she had not pursued her complaint to police in 2008 after being told it would lead to a "[[media circus]]".{{cite news |url= https://www.bbc.co.uk/news/entertainment-arts-19820017 |title= Jimmy Savile: Sussex police confirm 2008 assault claim |publisher=BBC News |date=3 October 2012 |accessdate=4 October 2012}} The founder of [[ChildLine]], [[Esther Rantzen]], was shown the interviews by Williams-Thomas and commented that, "There were always rumours that [Savile] behaved very inappropriately sexually with children."{{cite news |url= http://news.sky.com/story/991538/esther-rantzen-rumours-followed-jimmy-savile |title=Esther Rantzen: Rumours Followed Jimmy Savile |publisher=[[Sky News]] |date=1 October 2012}} An update to the original documentary, ''Exposure Update: The Jimmy Savile Investigation'', was shown on ITV on 21 November.{{cite news |author=Midgley, Neil |url= https://www.telegraph.co.uk/news/uknews/crime/jimmy-savile/9694258/The-Jimmy-Savile-Investigation-Exposure-Update-ITV1-review.html |newspaper=The Daily Telegraph |location =London |title= The Jimmy Savile Investigation: Exposure Update, ITV1, review |date=22 November 2012 |accessdate= 23 November 2012}} It won a [[Peabody Award]] in 2012.{{cite web|url=http://www.peabodyawards.com/award-profile/exposure-the-other-side-of-jimmy-savile-and-exposure-banaz-an-honour-killin |title="Exposure: Banaz: An Honour Killing" and "Exposure: The Other Side of Jimmy Savile" |publisher=The Peabody Awards |date= |accessdate=7 March 2017}} ===BBC comments and investigations=== Newspaper reports claimed [[Douglas Muggeridge]], controller of [[BBC Radio 1]] in the early 1970s, was aware of allegations against Savile, and asked for a report in 1973.{{cite news |first=Liam |last=O'Brien |url= https://www.independent.co.uk/news/uk/crime/boss-of-radio-1-knew-jimmy-savile-was-abusing-young-girls-8196555.html |title=Boss of Radio 1 'knew Jimmy Savile was abusing young girls' |newspaper=[[The Independent]] |location =London |date=4 October 2012 |accessdate=4 October 2012}} [[Derek Chinnery]], controller of Radio 1 from 1978 to 1985, recalled an occasion when he confronted Savile, saying, "I asked, 'What's all this, these rumours we hear about you Jimmy?' And he said, 'That's all nonsense'. There was no reason to disbelieve."{{cite news |url= https://www.independent.co.uk/news/uk/crime/saviles-alleged-abuse-could-have-spanned-six-decades-police-say-8210567.html |title= Savile's alleged abuse could have spanned six decades, police say |work=The Independent on Sunday |author=Singh, Arj |location =London |date=14 October 2012 |accessdate=14 October 2012}} [[Michael Grade]] told [[Channel 4 News]] that during his time at the BBC he had "fleetingly" heard rumours about Savile, but described claims of a [[cover-up]] as "ludicrous".{{cite news |url= http://www.channel4.com/news/jimmy-savile-met-launches-investigation |title=Michael Grade: There were question marks over Savile |work=[[Channel 4 News]] |date=2 October 2012 |accessdate=4 October 2012}} The BBC said no evidence of allegations of misconduct or actual misconduct by Savile had been found in its files{{cite news |url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/news/entertainment-arts-19776872 |title=Jimmy Savile accused of sexual abuse |publisher=BBC News |date=1 October 2012 |accessdate=1 October 2012}} and denied there had been a cover-up of his activities.{{cite news |first=Josh |last=Halliday |url= https://www.theguardian.com/media/2012/oct/01/jimmy-savile-bbc |title=Jimmy Savile: BBC denies cover-up |work=The Guardian |location =London |date=2 October 2012 |accessdate=2 October 2012}}{{cite news |url= https://www.bbc.co.uk/news/entertainment-arts-19776872 |title=Jimmy Savile accused of sexual abuse |publisher=BBC News |date=2 October 2012 |accessdate=2 October 2012}} On 8 October, the [[Director-General of the BBC]], [[George Entwistle]], apologised for what had happened and said further internal investigations would take place.{{cite news |url= https://www.bbc.co.uk/news/uk-19867830 |title=Jimmy Savile abuse claims: BBC apologises and pledges inquiry |publisher=BBC News |date=8 October 2012 |accessdate=8 October 2012}} The chairman of the [[BBC Trust]], [[Chris Patten|Lord Patten]], said the investigation would be set up as soon as police enquiries had been completed, and would be chaired by a figure from outside the BBC.{{cite news |url= https://www.bbc.co.uk/news/uk-19899354 |title= Jimmy Savile abuse claims: Outsider to head BBC inquiry |publisher=BBC News |date=10 October 2012 |accessdate=10 October 2012}} As a result of the shelving of the ''Newsnight'' investigation into Savile's activities ([[#Aborted Newsnight report|see above]]), there were complaints on ''[[Newswatch (UK TV series)|Newswatch]]''. On 11 October 2012, Entwistle asked [[BBC Scotland]] director [[Ken MacQuarrie]] to look into staff concerns over the dropping of the item.{{cite news |url= https://www.bbc.co.uk/news/world-19918192 |title= Sir Jimmy Savile inquiry: BBC responds to staff concerns |publisher=BBC News |date=12 October 2012 |accessdate=12 October 2012}} He announced a review of BBC policy on [[child protection]], and an enquiry into its culture and practices, focusing on the years Savile worked there.{{cite news |url= https://www.theguardian.com/media/2012/oct/12/jimmy-savile-bbc-apology-inquiries |title= Jimmy Savile: BBC issues 'heartfelt apology' as two inquiries launched |newspaper=The Guardian |location =London |date=13 October 2012 |page=12 |accessdate=15 October 2012 |author1=Sabbagh, Dan |author2= Halliday, Josh |author3= O'Carroll, Lisa}}{{cite news |url= https://www.bbc.co.uk/news/uk-19929967 |title= Jimmy Savile sex abuse claims: George Entwistle statement |publisher=BBC News |date=12 October 2012 |accessdate=15 October 2012}} The BBC was criticised in [[Parliament of the United Kingdom|Parliament]] for its handling of the affair. [[Harriet Harman]] said the allegations "cast a stain" on the corporation. [[Culture Secretary]] [[Maria Miller]] said she was satisfied the BBC was taking the allegations very seriously, and dismissed calls for an independent inquiry. [[Labour Party (UK)|Labour]] leader [[Ed Miliband]] said an independent inquiry was the only way to ensure justice for those involved.{{cite news |url= https://www.bbc.co.uk/news/uk-19957143 |title= Ed Miliband calls for 'outsider' to probe over Savile scandal |publisher=BBC News |date=15 October 2012 |accessdate=15 October 2012}} Entwistle offered to appear before the [[Culture, Media and Sport Committee]] to explain the BBC's position and actions.{{cite news |url= https://www.bbc.co.uk/news/uk-19948782 |title= MPs say Jimmy Savile claims are 'stain on BBC' |publisher=BBC News |date=15 October 2012 |accessdate=15 October 2012}} On 16 October, the BBC appointed heads of two inquiries into events surrounding Savile. Former [[High Court judge (England and Wales)|High Court judge]] [[Janet Smith (judge)|Dame Janet Smith]], who led the [[The Shipman Inquiry|inquiry]] into [[serial killer]] [[Harold Shipman]], was to review the culture and practices of the BBC during the time Savile worked there,{{cite news |first=Rowena |last=Mason |url= https://www.telegraph.co.uk/news/politics/9613014/BBCs-Jimmy-Savile-probe-to-be-led-by-Harold-Shipman-inquiry-judge.html |title=BBC's Jimmy Savile probe to be led by Harold Shipman inquiry judge |newspaper=The Daily Telegraph |location =London |date=16 October 2012 |accessdate=16 October 2012}} and [[Nick Pollard]], a former [[Sky News]] executive, would look at why the ''Newsnight'' investigation was dropped shortly before transmission. A ''[[Panorama (TV series)|Panorama]]'' investigation into the BBC's actions was broadcast on 22 October 2012.{{cite web |url= https://www.bbc.co.uk/iplayer/episode/b01nspvr/Panorama_Jimmy_Savile_What_the_BBC_Knew/ |work=Panorama |title=Jimmy Savile – What the BBC Knew |publisher=BBC |format=(UK viewing only) |date=22 October 2012}} Entwistle declined to be interviewed, citing legal advice that BBC senior management should co-operate only with the police, the BBC's reviews and Parliament.{{cite news |last=Sabbagh |first=Dan |last2=Plunkett |first2=John |url= https://www.theguardian.com/media/2012/oct/19/jimmy-savile-scandal-bbc-panorama |title=Jimmy Savile scandal: BBC chief refuses Panorama interview |newspaper=The Guardian |location =London |date=19 October 2012 |accessdate=19 October 2012}} On 21 October it was reported that Jones had warned Rippon in December 2011 that the BBC risked being accused of a cover-up if the item was dropped.{{cite news |url= https://www.bbc.co.uk/news/uk-20024074 |title=Newsnight journalist warned of BBC Savile scandal |publisher=BBC News |date=21 October 2012 |accessdate=21 October 2012}} On 22 October the BBC announced Rippon would "step aside" from his role of editor with immediate effect.{{cite news |first=Rob |last= Williams |url= https://www.independent.co.uk/news/uk/home-news/newsnight-editor-peter-rippon-steps-aside-over-jimmy-savile-claims-8220491.html |title=Newsnight editor Peter Rippon 'steps aside' over Jimmy Savile claims |newspaper= The Independent |location =London |date=22 October 2012 |accessdate=22 October 2012}}{{cite news |url= https://www.bbc.co.uk/news/world-20024904 |publisher=BBC News |title=BBC Newsnight editor steps aside over Jimmy Savile claims |date=22 October 2012 |accessdate=22 October 2012}} On the day after the ''Panorama'' broadcast, Entwistle appeared before the Parliamentary Culture, Media and Sport Committee, at which he faced hostile questioning and stated that it had been a "catastrophic mistake" to cancel the ''Newsnight'' broadcast.{{cite news |url= https://www.telegraph.co.uk/news/uknews/crime/jimmy-savile/9628228/Jimmy-Savile-George-Entwistle-heckled-by-BBC-reporters-after-brutal-grilling-from-MPs.html |title=Jimmy Savile: George Entwistle heckled by BBC reporters after brutal grilling from MPs |newspaper=The Daily Telegraph |location =London |date=23 October 2012 |accessdate=23 October 2012}} [[Paul Gambaccini]], who worked next door to Savile's office at BBC Radio 1 from 1973, said he was aware of rumours of Savile being a [[necrophile]] and stated:{{cite news |url= https://www.independent.co.uk/news/uk/crime/paul-gambaccini-aware-of-accusations-linking-jimmy-savile-to-necrophilia-8223217.html |title=Paul Gambaccini 'aware of accusations' linking Jimmy Savile to necrophilia |work=The Independent |location =London |author=Milmo, Cahal |date=24 October 2012 |accessdate=24 October 2012}}
"The expression which I came to associate with Savile's sex partners was ... the now politically incorrect 'under-age subnormals'. He targeted the institutionalised, the hospitalised – and this was known. Why did Jimmy Savile go to hospitals? That's where the patients were."
Gambaccini claimed that Savile [[bribe]]d the police.{{cite web|author=|url=http://www.bbc.co.uk/programmes/b01ngp7y |title=BBC Radio 5 live - 5 live Breakfast, 23/10/2012 |publisher=Bbc.co.uk |date=23 October 2012 |accessdate=7 March 2017}}{{cite web|url=https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=NEycF-pprk8&feature=watch_response |title=YouTube |publisher=YouTube |date= |accessdate=7 March 2017}} Sir Roger Jones, former chairman of ''[[Children in Need]]'', the BBC's annual [[telethon]] to support disadvantaged children and young people, said Savile had been barred from involvement because of rumours about an inappropriate interest in young girls. Savile had appeared on the telethon in 1984, 1987 and 1989 before Jones became chairman.{{cite web |title= Jimmy Savile: Children in Need had ban – Sir Roger Jones |url= https://www.bbc.co.uk/news/uk-wales-20120302 |publisher=BBC News |accessdate=29 October 2012 |date=29 October 2012}}{{cite news |title= 'Creepy' Jimmy Savile was banned from Children in Need |url= https://www.telegraph.co.uk/news/uknews/crime/jimmy-savile/9640407/Creepy-Jimmy-Savile-was-banned-from-Children-in-Need.html |accessdate=29 October 2012 |newspaper=The Daily Telegraph |location =London |date=29 October 2012}} The report by Pollard into the BBC's handling of the affair was published on 19 December 2012. It concluded that the decision to drop the ''Newsnight'' report on the allegations against Savile in December 2011 was "flawed", but that it had not been done to protect the Savile tribute programmes. However, it criticised Entwistle for apparently failing to read emails warning him of Savile's "dark side",{{cite news |last= Halliday |first= Josh |url= https://www.theguardian.com/media/2012/dec/19/pollard-report-george-entwistle-jimmy-savile |title=Pollard report: George Entwistle 'did not read emails' about Jimmy Savile |newspaper=The Guardian |location =London |date=19 December 2012 |accessdate=19 December 2012}} and that, after the allegations against Savile eventually became public, the BBC fell into a "level of chaos and confusion [that] was even greater than was apparent at the time".{{cite news |last1=Sabbagh |first1=Dan |last2=Plunkett |first2=John |url= https://www.theguardian.com/media/2012/dec/19/pollard-inquiry-bbc-jimmy-savile |title=Pollard inquiry: BBC 'incapable' of dealing with Jimmy Savile affair |newspaper=The Guardian |location= London |date=19 December 2012 |accessdate=19 December 2012}} The BBC announced that Rippon and ''Newsnight'' deputy editor Liz Gibbons would be replaced. Transcripts of evidence to the Pollard inquiry, together with emails and other submissions, were published on 22 February 2013.{{cite news |last=O'Mahony |first=Jennifer |url= https://www.telegraph.co.uk/news/uknews/crime/jimmy-savile/9887449/BBC-releases-Pollard-report-into-the-Savile-inquiry-live.html |title=BBC releases Pollard report into the Savile inquiry |newspaper=The Daily Telegraph |location= London |date=22 February 2013 |accessdate=22 February 2013}}{{cite news |last1=Halliday |first1=Josh |last2=Kiss |first2= Jemima |url= https://www.theguardian.com/media/2013/feb/22/bbc-jimmy-savile-scandal-transcripts |title=BBC releases Jimmy Savile scandal transcripts |newspaper=The Guardian |location= London |date=22 February 2013 |accessdate=22 February 2013}} Jones, who first broke the scandal, was terminated from the BBC in February 2015.{{cite news |url= https://www.theguardian.com/commentisfree/2015/mar/08/bbc-whistleblowers-jimmy-savile |title=The sinister treatment of dissent at the BBC |author=Cohen, Nick |work=The Observer |location= London |date=8 March 2015 |accessdate=13 June 2015}} Mackean, who was also involved in the ''Newsnight'' report, left the BBC in early 2013, and stated, "When the Savile scandal broke, the BBC tried to smear my reputation." Tom Giles, the editor of ''Panorama'' that aired the investigation on Savile on 22 October 2012, is now in an administrative position at BBC.{{cite news |author=Conlan, Tara; Halliday, Josh |url= https://www.theguardian.com/media/2014/may/16/bbc-panorama-editor-tom-giles-leaves-role |title=BBC Panorama editor Tom Giles leaves role after four years |work=The Guardian |date=16 May 2014 |accessdate=13 June 2015}} Clive Edwards, who as commissioning editor for current affairs oversaw the ''Panorama'' documentary, was decommissioned.{{cite news |url= https://www.c21media.net/bbc-factual-revamp-revealed/ |title=BBC factual revamp revealed |publisher=C21Media |date=5 March 2015 |accessdate=13 June 2015}} ====Dame Janet Smith review==== {{Main article|Dame Janet Smith Review}} In November 2012, Dame Janet Smith called for evidence, from people who were the subject of inappropriate sexual conduct by Savile on BBC premises, or on location for the BBC; people who knew of or suspected such conduct; anyone who raised concerns about Savile's conduct within the BBC; people who worked for or with Savile on programmes at the BBC between about 1964 and 2007, or who were familiar with "the culture or practices of the BBC during that time insofar as they may have been relevant to preventing or enabling the sexual abuse of children, young people or teenagers"; and people who held senior positions at the BBC who may have relevant information.{{cite web |url= http://www.damejanetsmithreview.com/ |title=Appeal for witnesses – Jimmy Savile |publisher=The Dame Janet Smith Review |date=November 2012 |accessdate=24 December 2012}}{{cite news |url= https://www.bbc.co.uk/news/uk-20325913 |title=Jimmy Savile scandal: Dame Janet Smith seeks witnesses |publisher=BBC News |date=14 November 2012 |accessdate=24 December 2012}} By 5 December 2012, the review's team had been contacted by "over 290" individuals, including many former or current BBC employees.{{cite web |url= http://www.damejanetsmithreview.com/updates/ |title=Update: 5 December 2012 |publisher= The Dame Janet Smith Review |date=5 December 2012 |accessdate=24 December 2012}} On 1 May 2015 it was announced that the review report was finished, but it could not be published as it might prejudice ongoing police investigations.{{cite web |url= http://www.damejanetsmithreview.com/updates/ |title=Updates |publisher=Dame Janet Smith Review |date= |accessdate=13 June 2015}} The review was published 25 February 2016. The review, which totalled more than 700 pages, found Savile had sexually abused 72 people and had [[rape]]d eight people, including an eight-year-old, at "virtually every one of the BBC premises at which he worked". Smith stated that some BBC staff members were aware of complaints against Savile but did not pass the information to senior management due to the "culture of not complaining." She described an "atmosphere of fear" still existing at the BBC and said that some of those interviewed for the inquiry did so only after being assured their names would not be published, as they feared reprisal. A separate report into the offending of [[Stuart Hall (presenter)|Stuart Hall]], another BBC presenter, was released the same day.{{cite news|last1=Bilefsky|first1=Dan|title=Jimmy Savile Inquiry Accuses BBC of Failing to Report Sexual Abuse|url=https://www.nytimes.com/2016/02/26/world/europe/jimmy-savile-report-bbc.html?_r=0|work=The New York Times|date=25 February 2016|accessdate=29 February 2016}} ==New allegations== Following the broadcast of the ITV documentary, many people came forward to make allegations about Savile's conduct towards young people. Some abuse was said to have taken place on BBC premises.{{cite news |first= Jennifer |last=O'Mahony |url= https://www.telegraph.co.uk/news/9603743/Jimmy-Savile-BBC-did-nothing-when-director-caught-him-in-the-act.html |title=Jimmy Savile: BBC did nothing when director caught him in the act |newspaper=The Daily Telegraph |location =London |date=12 October 2012 |accessdate=12 October 2012}} It was claimed that Savile had abused at least one boy as well as numerous girls.{{cite news |first=Martin |last=Beckford |first2=Richard |last2=Alleyne |url= https://www.telegraph.co.uk/news/uknews/crime/9588692/Met-investigate-Sir-Jimmy-Savile-as-dozens-more-abuse-allegations-are-made.html |title=Met investigate Sir Jimmy Savile as dozens more abuse allegations are made |newspaper=The Daily Telegraph |location =London |date=5 October 2012 |accessdate=5 October 2012}} Claims were made about Savile's activities in hospitals. It was claimed that he sexually abused a 13-year-old patient during a visit to [[Stoke Mandeville Hospital]] in 1971 and an eight-year-old girl in the same hospital recovering from an operation.{{cite news|author=John Hall |url=https://www.independent.co.uk/news/people/news/status-quo-frontman-francis-rossi-jimmy-savile-invited-me-to-sex-party-in-his-dressing-room-8282508.html |title=Status Quo frontman Francis Rossi: Jimmy Savile invited me to 'sex party' in his dressing room |publisher=The Independent |date=5 November 2012 |accessdate=7 March 2017}} Staff reported he searched the wards for young patients to abuse, and they instructed patients in the children's ward to feign sleep during his visits.{{cite news |author=Beckford, Martin |author2= Marsden, Sam |author3= Furness, Hannah |url= https://www.telegraph.co.uk/news/uknews/crime/9600123/Jimmy-Savile-did-ward-rounds-at-Stoke-Mandeville-to-find-young-girls-to-abuse.html |title=Jimmy Savile did 'ward rounds' at Stoke Mandeville to find young girls to abuse |newspaper=The Daily Telegraph |location =London |date=10 October 2012 |accessdate=11 October 2012}} A hospital spokesman said, though it was working with the police, it had no record of inappropriate behaviour by Savile.{{cite news |url= https://www.bbc.co.uk/news/uk-england-19907206 |title= Jimmy Savile: Stoke Mandeville patient's abuse claim |publisher=BBC News |date=11 October 2012 |accessdate=13 October 2012}} The BBC carried statements from a retired detective inspector of the local police force that a nurse at Stoke Mandeville hospital had reported Savile's abuse of patients there to him in the 1970s and he had repeatedly informed his superiors about this, but they did not believe him.{{cite news |last=Addley |first=Ester |title= Jimmy Savile's Broadmoor role came with a bedroom and keys |url= https://www.theguardian.com/media/2012/oct/12/jimmy-savile-broadmoor-volunteer-role?newsfeed=true |accessdate=3 July 2014 |work=The Guardian |location= London |date=12 October 2012}} A former nurse said she saw Savile molest a brain-damaged patient at Leeds hospital, saying, "He kissed her, and I thought he was a visitor coming to see her, and he started rubbing his hands down her arms and then I don't know of a nice way to put it but he molested her."{{cite news |first1=Martin |last1=Beckford |first2=Sam |last2=Marsden |first3=Hannah |last3=Furness |url= https://www.telegraph.co.uk/news/uknews/crime/9600881/Sir-Jimmy-Savile-new-allegations-presenter-abused-sick-children.html |title=Sir Jimmy Savile: new allegations presenter abused sick children |newspaper=The Daily Telegraph |location =London |date=11 October 2012 |accessdate=11 October 2012}} Savile was a volunteer at the adult high-security psychiatric [[Broadmoor Hospital]], and in August 1988 was appointed to chair an interim task force overseeing the management of the hospital, after its management board had been suspended.{{cite web |url= http://hansard.millbanksystems.com/lords/1988/nov/07/mentally-ill-offenders-treatment-1#S5LV0501P0_19881107_HOL_188 |title=Mentally Ill Offenders: Treatment |author=[[Alexander Scrymgeour, 12th Earl of Dundee|The Earl of Dundee]] |publisher=Hansard (Lords) |id=HL Deb 7 November 1988 vol 501 c525 |date=7 November 1988 |accessdate=13 October 2012}} It is alleged that Savile had hospital keys and access to patients' rooms. In a separate allegation, a lawyer said a client had been abused by Savile when he was a 10-year-old at the [[Haut de la Garenne]] children's home in Jersey.{{cite news |url= https://www.bbc.com/news/world-europe-jersey-19932105 |title= Jimmy Savile 'assaulted 10-year-old boy in Jersey' |publisher=BBC News |date=12 October 2012 |accessdate=12 October 2012}} [[Julie Fernandez]], who later appeared in BBC television programmes ''[[Eldorado (TV series)|Eldorado]]'' and ''[[The Office (UK TV series)|The Office]]'', was invited to a BBC studio to appear on ''Jim'll Fix It''. She recalled her experience in a radio interview: "I was in my wheelchair, but I just remember [Savile's] hands being everywhere and just lingering those two, three, four seconds slightly too long in places they shouldn't [...] It was in a busy room full of people in a studio so it was quite discreetly done and you don't kind of realise what's happening at the time, especially when you're 14 and it's the first time you've ever been in a studio and you're very excited. But I do remember feeling uncomfortable and he had these huge rings on his fingers."{{cite news |url= https://www.bbc.co.uk/news/uk-england-19925372 |title=Jimmy Savile 'groped Julie Fernandez when she was 14' |publisher=BBC News |date=12 October 2012 |accessdate=12 October 2012}}{{cite news |url= http://www.irishtimes.com/newspaper/breaking/2012/1012/breaking54.html |title=Savile 'groped' The Office actor |newspaper=[[The Irish Times]] |location=Dublin |agency=Press Association |date=12 October 2012 |accessdate=12 October 2012}}{{cite news |first=David |last=Seymour |url= http://www.peterboroughtoday.co.uk/news/local/tv-star-speaks-to-pt-about-jimmy-savile-s-wandering-hands-1-4365243 |title=TV star speaks to PT about Jimmy Savile's 'wandering hands' |newspaper=[[Peterborough Evening Telegraph]] |date=13 October 2012 |accessdate=13 October 2012}} Singer [[Coleen Nolan]] said Savile invited her to a hotel when she was 14 and had been involved in a TV recording at the ''Top of the Pops'' studio and that it made her "uncomfortable", "But you didn't talk about those things then."{{cite news |first1=Martin |last1=Beckford |first2=Hannah |last2=Furness |url= https://www.telegraph.co.uk/news/9585196/Jimmy-Savile-invited-me-to-hotel-when-I-was-14-claims-Coleen-Nolan.html |title=Coleen Nolan: Jimmy Savile invited me to hotel when I was 14 |newspaper=The Daily Telegraph |location =London |date=3 October 2012 |accessdate=3 October 2012}} Savile's [[Nephew and niece|great-niece]] Caroline Robinson said she had been sexually abused by him twice at family gatherings. She believed some members of the family knew about his abuse but had turned a blind eye to it. The British Prime Minister, [[David Cameron]], said that he was "truly shocked" by the published allegations, which should be "properly investigated".{{cite news |url= https://www.bbc.co.uk/news/uk-19863322 |title= Jimmy Savile abuse claims: Charity 'may change name' |publisher=BBC News |date=7 October 2012 |accessdate=7 October 2012}} The [[Jimmy Savile Charitable Trust]] stated that it was considering giving funds to those working with victims of sexual abuse, and that it may change its name because of the allegations; the trust later announced that it would close. As part of the investigations, enquiries would be made into allegations of abuse when Savile worked as a volunteer at [[Leeds General Infirmary]].{{cite news |url= https://www.bbc.co.uk/news/uk-england-leeds-19894010 |title= Jimmy Savile sex abuse inquiry 'to focus on Leeds hospital' |publisher=BBC News |date=10 October 2012 |accessdate=11 October 2012}} In October 2012, it was reported that the ''[[Sunday Mirror]]'' had decided not to publish allegations of sexual abuse at a children's home by two women against Savile. [[Paul Connew]], who was the newspaper's editor when the women came forward in 1994, described the allegations as "credible and convincing", but said that lawyers had advised against publication.{{cite news |url= https://www.theguardian.com/media/greenslade/2012/oct/10/jimmy-savile-bbc |first=Roy |last=Greenslade |title= Jimmy Savile: why the tabloids were unable to publish and be damned |newspaper=The Guardian |location= London |date=10 October 2012 |accessdate=17 July 2014}} In July 2013, Connew said that he believed that the newspaper would have lost a [[defamation|libel]] action over the allegations, as the two women, who had been pupils at Duncroft Approved School, did not want to be named. He also expressed concern that a jury would have been "starstruck" by Savile.{{cite news |url= http://www.pressgazette.co.uk/savile-story-dropped-sunday-mirror-because-paper-could-not-afford-lose-libel-battle |first=William |last=Turvill |title= Savile story dropped by Sunday Mirror because paper could not afford to lose libel battle |work= PressGazette |location= London |date=15 July 2013 |accessdate=17 July 2014}} In November 2014 the Health Secretary [[Jeremy Hunt (politician)|Jeremy Hunt]] announced that the enquiry had been widened, with the number of NHS organisations investigating allegations of abuse by Savile extended to 41.{{cite web|url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/news/health-29932391|title=BBC News - Jimmy Savile NHS hospital abuse inquiry widens|work=BBC News}} ==Police and related investigations== ===Operation Yewtree=== {{main article|Operation Yewtree}} The [[Metropolitan Police Service]] stated on 4 October 2012 that its Child Abuse Investigation Command would lead a process of assessing the allegations.{{cite news |url= https://www.bbc.co.uk/news/uk-19837906 |title=Met Police to assess Jimmy Savile claims |publisher=BBC News |date=4 October 2012 |accessdate=4 October 2012}} By 9 October the Metropolitan Police had formally recorded eight allegations against Savile, but announced that it was following up 120 lines of inquiry, addressing up to 25 alleged victims of abuse, mainly girls aged between 13 and 16. These covered a period spanning four decades, from 1959 until the 1980s, and were on "a national scale". An inquiry process, known as [[Operation Yewtree]], was set up jointly with the [[National Society for the Prevention of Cruelty to Children]] (NSPCC), and involving other organisations including the BBC and ITV. Commander Peter Spindler, head of specialist crime investigations, said: "At this stage it is quite clear from what women are telling us that Savile was a predatory sex offender."{{cite news |url= https://www.bbc.co.uk/news/uk-19887019 |title=Savile abuse claims: Police pursue 120 lines of inquiry |publisher=BBC News |date=9 October 2012 |accessdate=9 October 2012}} On 19 October 2012 the Metropolitan Police launched a formal criminal investigation into historic allegations of child sex abuse by Savile over four decades. It stated that it was pursuing over 400 separate lines of inquiry based on evidence of 200 witnesses via 14 police forces across the UK. Commander Spindler said: "We are dealing with alleged abuse on an unprecedented scale. The profile of this operation has empowered a staggering number of victims to come forward to report the sexual exploitation which occurred during their childhood." John Cameron of the NSPCC said that Savile was "a well-organised prolific sex offender, who's used his power, his authority, his influence to procure children and offend against them." On 25 October the police reported that the number of possible victims was "fast approaching 300".{{cite news |url= https://www.bbc.co.uk/news/uk-20081021 |title= Jimmy Savile: Number of victims reach 300, police say |date=25 October 2012 |publisher=BBC News |accessdate=25 October 2012}} It was also reported that police were looking at allegations that three doctors in hospitals with which Savile had been associated had been involved in the abuse of young people in their care.{{cite news |url= https://www.theguardian.com/media/2012/oct/24/jimmy-savile-sex-abuse-doctors |title= Jimmy Savile inquiry looking at alleged sexual abuse by three doctors |newspaper=The Guardian |location =London |author1= Laville, Sandra |author2= O'Carroll, Lisa |date=24 October 2012 |accessdate=25 October 2012}} By 19 December, eight people had been arrested for questioning, and later bailed, as part of the inquiry. These included former pop star [[Gary Glitter]];{{cite news |last=Booth |first=Robert |title=Gary Glitter arrested by police on Jimmy Savile case |url= https://www.theguardian.com/global/2012/oct/28/gary-glitter-arrest-jimmy-savile |accessdate=29 October 2012 |newspaper=The Guardian |location =London |date=28 October 2012}}{{cite news |url= 'sexual offences' |newspaper=The Sunday Telegraph |location =London |author=Hough, Andrew |date=28 October 2012 |accessdate=28 October 2012}}{{cite news |url= https://www.bbc.co.uk/news/uk-20114378 2012 |accessdate=2 November 2012 |newspaper =The Independent |location =London}} former BBC producers Wilfred De'ath{{cite news |author= Ford Rojas, John-Paul |url=
