Ted Beston would not face prosecution due to insufficient evidence.{{cite news |url= https://www.bbc.co.uk/news/uk-22526051 |publisher=BBC News |title= Savile producer Ted Beston 'relieved' as police drop action |date=14 May 2013 |accessdate=15 May 2013}} On 12 December, Commander Peter Spindler said that the investigation had been completed and that the report of Operation Yewtree was being prepared for publication early in 2013. He said that a total of 589 alleged victims of abuse had come forward in the inquiry, of whom 450 alleged abuse by Savile. Of the alleged victims, 82% were female and 80% were children or young people. There were 31 allegations of rape by Savile across seven [[Police area#Current police areas of Great Britain|police force areas]]. Commander Spindler said: "Savile's offending peaked in the 70s and what we... will be showing... is how he used his position in society... to get his sexual gratification." The operation had involved 30 police officers, and its cost so far was estimated at about £2 million. On 11 January 2013, ''[[Giving Victims a Voice]]'', a report into allegations of sexual abuse made against Jimmy Savile under Operation Yewtree by the [[Metropolitan Police Service]] and the NSPCC was published under the logo of the Crown Prosecution Service. Among its conclusions are that "It is now clear that Savile was hiding in plain sight and using his celebrity status and fundraising activity to gain uncontrolled access to vulnerable people across six decades. For a variety of reasons the vast majority of his victims did not feel they could speak out and it's apparent that some of the small number who did had their accounts dismissed by those in authority including parents and carers."{{cite web |url= http://www.nspcc.org.uk/news-and-views/our-news/child-protection-news/13-01-11-yewtree-report/yewtree-report-pdf_wdf93652.pdf |title=Giving Victims a Voice |publisher=Crown Prosecution Service |date=January 2013}}{{rp|6}} The document was given wide publicity throughout the media. Journalist [[Charles Moore (journalist)|Charles Moore]] wrote in ''The Daily Telegraph'' that he had read the whole report and it did not reveal the extent of abuse as the BBC website had stated in the lead headline "Jimmy Savile scandal: Report reveals extent of abuse". He remarked that there was no evidence in the report which a court would recognise. Instead it assumed that because uncorroborated allegations had been made, the offences were committed, and, treating allegations as facts, it declared that 214 incidents had now been "formally recorded" as crimes. Moore commented that by doing so the report undermined justice.{{cite news |author=Moore, Charles |url= https://www.telegraph.co.uk/news/uknews/crime/jimmy-savile/9795920/Treating-every-allegation-against-Jimmy-Savile-as-a-fact-undermines-justice.html |title= Treating every allegation against Jimmy Savile as a fact undermines justice |date=11 January 2013 |newspaper=The Daily Telegraph |location =London}} Jonathan Brown, writing in ''[[The Independent]]'', said that the report "revealed a man who used his celebrity status and outwardly well-intended works to gain access to and ultimately rape and sexually exploit hundreds of vulnerable young star-struck victims..."{{cite news |url= https://www.independent.co.uk/news/uk/crime/jimmy-savile-a-report-that-reveals-54-years-of-abuse-by-the-man-who-groomed-the-nation-8447146.html |title=Jimmy Savile: A report that reveals 54 years of abuse by the man who groomed the nation |work=The Independent |location=London |date=6 May 2013 |accessdate=6 May 2013 |author=Brown, Jonathan}} In March 2013 Her Majesty's Inspectorate of Constabulary reported that 214 of the complaints that had been made against Savile after his death would have been criminal offences if they had been reported at the time. Sixteen persons reported being raped by Savile under the age of 16 and four of those were under the age of ten. Thirteen others reported serious sexual abuse by Savile, including four under-ten-year-olds. Another ten reported being raped by Savile while over the age of sixteen.{{cite web|url=http://www.hmic.gov.uk/media/review-into-allegations-and-intelligence-material-concerning-jimmy-savile.pdf |title="Mistakes were made." HMIC's review into allegations and intelligence material concerning Jimmy Savile between 1964 and 2012 |format=PDF |date= |accessdate=7 March 2017}} DJ and friend of Savile [[Ray Teret]] was found guilty of seven rapes and 11 indecent assaults in December 2014; while Teret was cleared of aiding and abetting Savile to rape a 15-year-old girl, he was found guilty of raping the same complainant.{{cite news |title= Jimmy Savile's friend Ray Teret guilty of raping one of BBC presenter's victims |author= Evans, Martin |date=5 December 2014 |url= https://www.telegraph.co.uk/news/uknews/crime/jimmy-savile/11255050/Jimmy-Saviles-friend-Ray-Teret-guilty-of-raping-one-of-BBC-presenters-victims.html |work=The Daily Telegraph |location= London |accessdate=12 December 2014}} An attorney for 169 of Savile's alleged victims stated that Teret's guilty verdicts represent "the closest the victims of Jimmy Savile will get to a conviction against their attacker".{{cite news |title= Lawyer: Savile victims will take comfort from Teret verdict |url= http://www.itv.com/news/update/2014-12-05/lawyer-savile-victims-will-take-comfort-from-teret-verdict/ |work=ITV News |date=5 December 2014 |accessdate=12 December 2014}} ===Crown Prosecution Service=== On 24 October 2012 the [[Crown Prosecution Service]] said the [[Director of Public Prosecutions]], [[Keir Starmer]], would review the service's decisions not to prosecute Savile in 2009 in relation to four claims against him for sexual abuse dating back to the 1970s.{{cite news |url= https://www.telegraph.co.uk/news/uknews/crime/jimmy-savile/9630550/Jimmy-Savile-What-George-Entwistle-told-MPs-about-Panorama-justthewomen-Newsnight-and-the-conversation-at-the-Hilton-Hotel.html |author=Furness, Hannah |title=Jimmy Savile: Director of Public Prosecutions to review why CPS did not prosecute |work=The Daily Telegraph |location =London |date=24 October 2012 |accessdate=24 October 2012}} The report, prepared by the principal legal advisor to the DPP, Alison Levitt QC, was published on 11 January 2013. It found that, if police and prosecutors had taken a different approach towards the allegations, prosecutions could have been possible in relation to three of the claims.{{cite news |url= https://www.bbc.co.uk/news/uk-20992789 |title= Jimmy Savile scandal: Chances to prosecute 'were missed' |publisher=BBC News |date=11 January 2013 |accessdate=12 January 2013}}{{cite web |url= http://www.cps.gov.uk/news/press_statements/dpp_statement_about_savile_cases/executive_summary_on_jimmy_savile_cases_report/ |publisher=Crown Prosecution Service |title= In the matter of the late Jimmy Savile: Report to the Director of Public Prosecutions by Alison Levitt Q.C. |accessdate=12 January 2013 |date=January 2013}} Keir Starmer apologised for the shortcomings of the CPS and criticised two police forces for taking an "unjustifiably cautious" approach.{{cite news |url= https://www.telegraph.co.uk/news/uknews/crime/jimmy-savile/9795128/Jimmy-Savile-police-missed-three-chances-to-take-case-to-trial-DPP-admits.html |title=Jimmy Savile police missed three chances to take case to trial, DPP admits |work=The Daily Telegraph |location =London |date=11 January 2013 |accessdate=12 January 2013}} In November 2013, shortly after he left the position of [[Director of Public Prosecutions]], Keir Starmer called for mandatory reporting which would compel all professionals such as teachers, doctors and social workers to report suspicions of child abuse or face legal consequences in the light of the scandal.{{cite news|author=Kunal Dutta |url=https://www.independent.co.uk/news/uk/crime/without-a-change-in-the-law-therell-be-another-savile--keir-starmer-says-professionals-should-be-forced-to-report-suspected-child-abuse-8920031.html |title=‘Without a change in the law, there’ll be another Savile’ - Keir Starmer says professionals should be forced to report suspected child abuse |publisher=The Independent |date=4 November 2013 |accessdate=7 March 2017}} ===HMIC assessment of police investigations=== The [[Home Secretary]], [[Theresa May]], announced on 6 November 2012 that [[Her Majesty's Inspectorate of Constabulary]] would also carry out an assessment of all the investigations relating to Savile undertaken by police forces across the country, examine whether allegations were properly investigated, and identify any related issues.{{cite press release |url= http://www.homeoffice.gov.uk/media-centre/news/historic-abuse-allegations |publisher=Home Office |title= Home Secretary's statement on historic allegations of child abuse in north Wales |date=6 November 2012 |accessdate=9 November 2012}} On 12 March 2013, a report entitled "Mistakes were made: HMIC's review into allegations and intelligence material concerning Jimmy Savile between 1964 and 2012" was published, which included material showing that police had received intelligence about Savile's sexual conduct dating back to 1963.{{cite news |url= https://www.bbc.co.uk/news/uk-21756150|title=The missed chances to get Jimmy Savile |publisher=BBC News |date=12 March 2013 |accessdate=13 March 2013}} ===Investigations in Jersey=== On 7 November 2012 it was announced that an inquiry would also be undertaken, by a senior legal figure from outside the island, into allegations that Savile had abused children at Haut de la Garenne in [[Jersey]].{{cite web|author=John-Paul Ford Rojas |url=https://www.telegraph.co.uk/news/uknews/crime/jimmy-savile/9661795/Independent-inquiry-to-examine-claims-of-Jersey-abuse.html |title=Independent inquiry to examine claims of Jersey abuse |publisher=Telegraph |date=7 November 2012 |accessdate=7 March 2017}} ===West Yorkshire Police report=== On 10 May 2013, [[West Yorkshire Police]] published a report into the relationship of the force with Savile. It concluded that he had not been protected from arrest or prosecution, but that there had been an "over-reliance on personal friendships" between Savile and some officers. The report states that there are "currently 76 crimes involving 68 victims committed in the West Yorkshire area relating to Savile", but none of them were reported to the police before his death. Nine of the incidents relate to persons under the age of nine, the youngest being aged five.{{cite news |url= https://www.bbc.co.uk/news/uk-england-22476937 |title=Jimmy Savile 'not protected' from arrest, West Yorkshire Police say |publisher=BBC News |date=10 May 2013 |accessdate=10 May 2013}} A copy of the report was to be passed to the [[Independent Police Complaints Commission]].{{cite news |url= https://www.theguardian.com/media/2013/may/09/west-yorkshire-police-jimmy-savile-report |title=West Yorkshire police to publish findings of Jimmy Savile report |agency=Press Association |work=The Guardian |location= London |date=9 May 2013 |accessdate=10 May 2013}} ===North Yorkshire Police report=== On 18 December 2014, [[North Yorkshire Police]] published a report of an internal inquiry into its actions. The inquiry, termed Operation Hibiscus, found no evidence of misconduct by officers, but also concluded that opportunities had been missed to prosecute both Savile and Peter Jaconelli, a former mayor of [[Scarborough, North Yorkshire|Scarborough]] who died in 1999, for child sex abuse. The report stated that 32 allegations had been made against Jaconelli, and five against Savile. Jaconelli was stripped of civic honours earlier in 2014 after allegations against him were first published by the ''North Yorks Enquirer''.{{cite web|author=Tim Hicks |url=http://nyenquirer.uk/vindicated-savile-jaconelli-cover-starts-unravel/ |title=North Yorks Enquirer Vindicated! Savile & Jaconelli: The Cover-Up Starts To Unravel North Yorks Enquirer |publisher=Nyenquirer.uk |date=20 September 2014 |accessdate=7 March 2017}} The Assistant Chief Constable of North Yorkshire Police, Paul Kennedy, said that the report showed that there would have been sufficient evidence for the Crown Prosecution Service to consider criminal charges against both Savile and Jaconelli if they were still alive.{{cite news |url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/news/uk-england-york-north-yorkshire-30514237 |title=Jimmy Savile and Peter Jaconelli sex abuse: Police admit chances were missed |publisher=BBC News |date=18 December 2014 |accessdate=18 December 2014}} ===Surrey Police report=== On 29 April 2015, [[Surrey Police]] published a report stating that Savile had sexually assaulted 22 students and a visitor at the Duncroft Approved School for Girls in [[Staines-upon-Thames]] between 1974 and 1979. The report said that Savile had committed at least 46 offences at the school, including one which would have been classed as rape under current law.{{cite news |url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/news/uk-england-32510543 |title=Surrey school pupils abused by Savile, police report says|work=BBC News |date=29 April 2015 |accessdate=29 April 2015}} ==Department of Health investigations== The [[Department of Health (United Kingdom)|Department of Health]] announced that former [[barrister]] [[Kate Lampard]] would chair the department's investigations into Savile's activities at [[Stoke Mandeville Hospital]], [[Leeds General Infirmary]], [[Broadmoor Hospital]] and other hospitals and facilities in England.{{cite news |url= https://www.bbc.co.uk/news/uk-19980979 |title=Jimmy Savile scandal: Kate Lampard to lead NHS investigation |publisher=BBC News |date=17 October 2012 |accessdate=17 October 2012}} In October 2013 the [[Secretary of State for Health]], [[Jeremy Hunt (politician)|Jeremy Hunt]], announced that inquiries had been extended to other, unnamed, hospitals. As at November 2013, the list of hospitals investigated included:{{Cite news|url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/news/uk-25153968|title=Jimmy Savile: 19 more hospitals to investigate links|publisher=BBC News|date=29 November 2013|accessdate=30 November 2013}} {{Div col}} # [[Barnet Hospital]] # [[Broadmoor Hospital]] # [[Royal Manchester Children's Hospital#History#Old Booth Hall Children's Hospital|Booth Hall Children's Hospital]] # [[Cardiff Royal Infirmary]] # [[Willerby, East Riding of Yorkshire|De La Pole Hospital]] # [[Mid Yorkshire Hospitals NHS Trust|Dewsbury Hospital]] # [[Dryburn Hospital]] # [[Exeter Hospital]] # [[Great Ormond Street Hospital]] # [[Hammersmith Hospital]] # [[High Royds Psychiatric Hospital]] # [[Leavesden Hospital|Leavesden Secure Mental Hospital]] # [[Leeds General Infirmary]] # [[The Royal Marsden NHS Foundation Trust|Marsden Hospital]] # [[Maudsley Hospital]] # Moss Side Hospital (formerly part of [[Ashworth Hospital]]) # [[North Manchester General Hospital]] # [[Salisbury District Hospital|Odstock Hospital]] # [[Mid Yorkshire Hospitals NHS Trust|Pinderfields Hospital]] # [[Royal Portsmouth Hospital|Portsmouth Hospital]] # Prestwich Psychiatric Hospital, [[Prestwich]] # Queen Mary's Hospital, [[Carshalton]] # [[Queen Victoria Hospital]], [[East Grinstead]] # [[Rampton Hospital]] # [[Royal Free Hospital]], London # [[Royal Victoria Infirmary]], [[Newcastle upon Tyne|Newcastle]] # [[Saxondale Hospital]] # [[Seacroft Hospital]], [[Leeds]] # [[Wirral University Teaching Hospital NHS Foundation Trust|St Catherine's Hospital Birkenhead]] # [[Stoke Mandeville Hospital]] # Whitby Memorial Hospital, [[Whitby]] # [[Wythenshawe Hospital]] {{div col end}} ===Findings=== The results of the investigations were made public by Hunt on 26 June 2014. The report concluded that Savile sexually assaulted victims in NHS hospitals over several decades. At Leeds General Infirmary, 60 people, including both staff and patients, stated that they had been abused by Savile, with their ages ranging from 5 to 75. It reported a number of organisational failures which had allowed him to continue unchallenged. Hunt apologised to the victims of the assaults, and said that the findings "will shake our country to the core". It was reported that Savile had boasted to nurses and other staff that he performed sex acts on the bodies of recently deceased persons in the mortuary of Leeds General Hospital and claimed to have removed glass eyes from corpses and made them into rings. The report says "We have no way of proving Savile's claims that he interfered with the bodies of the deceased patients in the mortuary in this way" but that Savile did have unsupervised access to the mortuary.{{cite news |last1=Halliday |first1=Josh |title=Jimmy Savile told hospital staff he performed sex acts on corpses in Leeds mortuary |url= https://www.theguardian.com/media/2014/jun/26/savile-bodies-sex-acts-corpses-glass-eyes-mortuary |accessdate=25 June 2014 |newspaper=The Guardian |location= London |date=25 June 2014}}{{cite news |last1=Davies |first1=Caroline |title=Jimmy Savile's victims were aged five to seventy-five at Leeds Hospital, inquiry finds |url= https://www.theguardian.com/media/2014/jun/26/jimmy-savile-victims-leeds-general-infirmary-investigators |accessdate=25 June 2014 |newspaper=The Guardian |location= London |date=25 June 2014}} A separate report on Savile's activities at [[Stoke Mandeville Hospital]], prepared by independent investigator Dr Androulla Johnstone and published on 26 February 2015, found that he had sexually abused more than 50 people there, including staff, patients and visitors. One was an 8-year-old child. Savile had full access to all parts of the hospital. The report stated that it was widely known at the hospital that Savile was a "sex pest", and that 10 complaints had been made at the time, but no action was taken.{{cite news |last1=Titheradge |first1=Noel |title=Savile abuse: Stoke Mandeville staff 'were told' |url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/news/uk-31611191 |accessdate=26 February 2015 |publisher=BBC News |date=26 February 2015}} Also published on 26 February 2015 was Kate Lampard's report into lessons to be learned from the health service's handling of the Savile scandal.{{cite news |title=Savile 'abused 63 people at Stoke Mandeville Hospital' |url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/news/uk-31637320 |accessdate=26 February 2015 |publisher=BBC News |date=26 February 2015}} She concluded that:{{cite web|url=https://www.gov.uk/government/uploads/system/uploads/attachment_data/file/407187/KL_lessons_learned_report_FINAL.pdf |title=Independent oversight of NHS and Department of Health investigations into matters relating to Jimmy Savill |publisher=GOV.UK |date=19 February 2015 |accessdate=7 March 2017}}
"Savile was a highly unusual personality whose lifestyle, behaviour and offending patterns were equally unusual. As a result of his celebrity, his volunteering, and his fundraising he had exceptional access to a number of NHS hospitals and took the opportunities that that access gave him to abuse patients, staff and others on a remarkable scale. Savile’s celebrity and his roles as a volunteer and fundraiser also gave him power and influence within NHS hospitals which meant that his behaviour, which was often evidently inappropriate, was not challenged as it should have been. Savile’s ability to continue to pursue his activities without effective challenge was aided by fragmented hospital management arrangements; social attitudes of the times, including reticence in reporting and accepting reports of sexual harassment and abuse, and greater deference than today towards those in positions of influence and power; and less bold and intrusive media reporting. While it might be tempting to dismiss the Savile case as wholly exceptional, a unique result of a perfect storm of circumstances, the evidence we have gathered indicates that there are many elements of the Savile story that could be repeated in the future. There is always a risk of the abuse, including sexual abuse, of people in hospitals. There will always be people who seek to gain undue influence and power within public institutions including in hospitals. And society and individuals continue to have a weakness for celebrities. Hospital organisations need to be aware of the risks posed by these matters and manage them appropriately."
==Department for Education== A report for the [[Department for Education]] reached no firm conclusions over whether Savile had abused children or staff when visiting schools and children's homes, or hosting shows at which they had been invited to attend, between the 1960s and 1980s. The report, published on 26 February 2015, brought together the findings of various investigations carried out by local authorities, charities and schools. The Children's Minister, [[Edward Timpson]], said that, though information had been received from credible sources, there was insufficient corroborating evidence to draw firm conclusions.{{cite news |title='No conclusions' on Savile in schools |url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/news/education-31640591 |accessdate=26 February 2015 |publisher=BBC News |date=26 February 2015}} ==Call for single inquiry== {{main article|Independent Inquiry into Child Sexual Abuse}} On 8 November 2012 the [[Shadow Home Secretary]], [[Yvette Cooper]], called in [[Parliament of the United Kingdom|Parliament]] for a single, overarching public inquiry to examine all recent allegations of child abuse, including those relating to the [[North Wales child abuse scandal]] and those related to Savile.{{cite news |url= http://news.bbc.co.uk/democracylive/hi/house_of_commons/newsid_9766000/9766976.stm |work=BBC Democracy Live |title=May announces details of child abuse investigations |date=6 November 2012 |accessdate=8 November 2012}} This was supported by former minister [[Tim Loughton]] and the NSPCC.{{cite web|url=https://www.theguardian.com/society/2012/nov/08/david-cameron-warns-witch-hunt-paedophilia |title=David Cameron warns against 'witch-hunt' amid paedophilia allegations | Society |publisher=The Guardian |date= |accessdate=7 March 2017}} An [[2014 United Kingdom child sexual abuse panel inquiry|overarching panel inquiry]] was announced by the [[Home Secretary]], [[Theresa May]], in July 2014, to examine how the country's institutions had handled their [[Duty of care in English law|duty of care]] to protect children from sexual abuse.{{cite news |url= https://www.bbc.co.uk/news/uk-politics-28203914 |title=Ex-senior judge Butler-Sloss to head child sex abuse inquiry |publisher=BBC News |date=8 July 2014 |accessdate=12 July 2014}} It is to be led by an independent panel of experts, and was to be chaired by [[Elizabeth Butler-Sloss, Baroness Butler-Sloss|Baroness Butler-Sloss]]. On 14 July it was announced that Baroness Butler-Sloss was standing down, and that a new chair would be appointed.{{cite news |url= https://www.bbc.co.uk/news/business-28295282 |title=Butler-Sloss steps down from child abuse inquiry |publisher=BBC News |date=14 July 2014 |accessdate=14 July 2014}} On 5 September it was announced that it would be chaired by [[Fiona Woolf]]{{cite news |url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/news/uk-politics-29076504|title=Lord Mayor Fiona Woolf to lead child abuse inquiry|publisher=[[BBC News Online]]|date=5 September 2014|accessdate=5 September 2014}} but on 31 October 2014 she too resigned from the role.{{Cite news|url = https://www.bbc.co.uk/news/uk-29853002|title = Fiona Woolf resigns as head of child abuse inquiry|last = |first = |date = 31 October 2014|work = |accessdate = 31 October 2014}} On 4 February 2015 May announced that the inquiry would be chaired by [[Judge|Justice]] [[Lowell Goddard]], a [[New Zealand High Court]] judge, and would be given new powers as a statutory inquiry.{{cite web | title= New Zealand judge Lowell Goddard to lead abuse inquiry |url= https://www.bbc.co.uk/news/uk-31130805| author=|date= 4 February 2015 | website= BBC News | accessdate=5 February 2015}} Dame Goddard resigned the chair of the Inquiry on 4 August 2016 to return to New Zealand but the Inquiry's work continued.{{cite news|last1=BBC Staff|title=Child sex abuse inquiry will continue 'without delay'|url=https://www.bbc.com/news/uk-36982049|accessdate=3 July 2017|work=BBC News|date=5 August 2016}} Dame Goddard later said that she was prevented from selecting her own staff and the Shirley Oaks Survivors Association withdrew from the Inquiry over concerns about its true independence.{{cite news|last1=Morris|first1=Jake|title=Survivors' group 'loses faith' in child sex abuse inquiry|url=https://www.bbc.com/news/uk-37303144|accessdate=3 July 2017|work=BBC News|date=8 September 2016}} ==Aftermath== [[File:Jimmy Savile, Headstone.jpg|thumb|right|Savile's ornate black [[granite]] and steel [[headstone]] stood for just 19 days. It was unveiled on 20 September 2012 and, following awareness of his abusive past, was removed, during the night of 9–10 October 2012, at his family's request "out of respect" to public opinion and others buried in and visiting the cemetery.]] Savile's family asked "out of respect to public opinion" that his gravestone be taken from the cemetery where his body is buried. [[Borough of Scarborough|Scarborough Borough Council]] and funeral directors removed it "under cover of night"{{cite news |url= http://news.sky.com/story/995632/jimmy-savile-headstone-removed-and-dumped |title=Jimmy Savile: Headstone Removed And Dumped |publisher=Sky News |date=10 October 2012 |accessdate=14 October 2012}} and sent it to landfill.{{cite news |url= https://www.bbc.co.uk/news/uk-england-york-north-yorkshire-19893373 |title=Jimmy Savile's headstone removed from Scarborough cemetery |publisher=BBC News |date=10 October 2012 |accessdate=14 October 2012}}{{cite news |url= http://www.irishtimes.com/newspaper/breaking/2012/1010/breaking3.html |title=Savile's headstone removed by family |newspaper=The Irish Times |location =Dublin |date=10 October 2012 |accessdate=14 October 2012}} It was announced that Savile's inscription in the wall of [[Leeds Civic Hall]] would be removed in October 2012.{{cite news |url= http://www.express.co.uk/posts/view/350965/Council-orders-removal-of-Sir-Jimmy-Savile-tribute |author=Jeeves, Paul |date=9 October 2012 |newspaper=Daily Express |location =London |title=Council orders removal of Jimmy Savile tribute}} In the same month a café at Stoke Mandeville Hospital, originally called "Jimmy's" and displaying a neon sign in the shape of Savile's signature, was renamed 'Cafe@WRVS'.{{cite web|url=https://www.bbc.com/news/uk-england-beds-bucks-herts-19974841|title=Jimmy Savile cafe renamed at Stoke Mandeville|date=17 October 2012|publisher=BBC News|accessdate=25 February 2018}} [[Cunard Line|Cunard]] cancelled a sail-past tribute to Savile's burial place at [[Scarborough, North Yorkshire|Scarborough]], scheduled for 15:00 BST on 1 August 2013.{{cite news |url= https://www.bbc.co.uk/news/uk-england-york-north-yorkshire-19922274 |title=Cunard cancels Sir Jimmy Savile Scarborough sail past |publisher=BBC News |date=12 October 2012 |accessdate=12 October 2012}}{{cite news |first=Jolyon |last=Attwooll |url= http://www.smh.com.au/travel/travel-incidents/cruise-line-abandons-jimmy-savile-tribute-sailby-20121012-27gwa.html |title=Cruise line abandons Jimmy Savile tribute sail-by |newspaper=[[The Sydney Morning Herald]] |date=12 October 2012 |accessdate=12 October 2012}} The [[University of Bedfordshire]] stripped Savile of the honorary degree it had awarded him in 2009.{{cite news |first=Tim |last=Walker |url= https://www.telegraph.co.uk/news/celebritynews/9605293/Sir-Jimmy-Savile-is-stripped-of-his-honorary-doctorate.html |title=Sir Jimmy Savile is stripped of his honorary doctorate |newspaper=The Daily Telegraph |location =London |date=13 October 2012 |accessdate=13 October 2012}} Savile's name was removed from the [[Great North Run]] Hall of Fame.{{cite news |first=Katie |last=Davies |url= http://www.chroniclelive.co.uk/communities/newcastle/2012/10/13/jimmy-savile-removed-from-great-north-run-history-72703-32025062/ |title=Jimmy Savile removed from Great North Run history |newspaper=[[Evening Chronicle]] |location =Newcastle |date=13 October 2012 |accessdate=13 October 2012}} On 23 October 2012 two [[registered charities in England and Wales|registered charities]], the Jimmy Savile Charitable Trust and the Jimmy Savile Stoke Mandeville Hospital Trust, set up to "provide funds for the relief of poverty and sickness and other charitable purposes beneficial to the community", announced they would close and have their funds redistributed to other charities.{{cite news |url= https://www.bbc.co.uk/news/uk-20001588 |title=Jimmy Savile charities have no future, say trustees |publisher=BBC News |date=23 October 2012 |accessdate=23 October 2012}} It was reported on 28 October 2012 that Savile's cottage in [[Glen Coe]] had been spray-painted with slogans and the door damaged.{{cite web |title=Savile's Glencoe home vandalised |url= https://www.bbc.co.uk/news/uk-scotland-20116281 |publisher=BBC News |accessdate=29 October 2012 |date=28 October 2012}} The cottage had been searched by police looking for evidence of others involved with him in abuse. Plans to sell the cottage early in 2012 were halted by Savile's charitable trust, which had planned to turn it into a respite centre for the disabled. These plans were in turn halted when the trust announced it would close. The cottage was sold at auction on 30 May 2013.{{cite news |last= Smith |first= Steve |title= Jimmy Savile's Glencoe home on sale for £310k |url= http://www.scotsman.com/news/scottish-news/top-stories/jimmy-savile-s-glencoe-home-on-sale-for-310k-1-2932120 |accessdate=16 May 2013 |newspaper=The Scotsman |location=Edinburgh |date=16 May 2013}}{{cite news |title= Jimmy Savile cottage in Glencoe sells for £212,000 |url= https://www.bbc.co.uk/news/uk-scotland-highlands-islands-22713282 |accessdate=31 May 2013 |publisher=BBC News |date=30 May 2013}} On 2 November it was reported that letters had been sent to Savile's estate, the BBC, Stoke Mandeville Hospital, Broadmoor, and Leeds General Infirmary by solicitors acting on behalf of 20 clients who claimed to have been abused by Savile, and that legal action against them was being considered.{{cite news |url= https://www.bbc.co.uk/news/uk-20184715 |title=Freddie Starr faces further questioning |publisher=BBC News |date=2 November 2012 |accessdate=2 November 2012}} In November 2012 the BBC confirmed that it would no longer be airing further repeats of ''[[Top of the Pops]]'' on [[BBC Four]] featuring Savile as a presenter.{{cite news |url= http://www.digitalspy.co.uk/tv/news/a435261/bbc-axes-jimmy-savile-top-of-the-pops-reruns.html |title= BBC axes Jimmy Savile 'Top of the Pops' reruns |work= Digital Spy |date= 2 November 2012|accessdate=13 September 2013}} On 20 January 2013 the BBC apologised after it had screened a 2001 episode of the children's programme ''[[Tweenies]]'' on [[CBeebies]], in which the character Max had presented a parody of ''Top of The Pops'', dressed up and with a hairstyle similar to Savile's, and also using some of his catchphrases.{{cite news |url= https://www.theguardian.com/tv-and-radio/2013/jan/20/bbc-jimmy-savile-parody-cbeebies |title=BBC apologises over Jimmy Savile parody on CBeebies |work=The Guardian |location= London |agency=Press Association |date=20 January 2013 |accessdate=20 January 2013}} In June 2015 a stage play about Savile and the abuse scandal was premiered at [[Park Theatre (London)|Park Theatre]] in [[Finsbury Park (area)|Finsbury Park]], London. Titled ''An Audience with Jimmy Savile'', it was written by [[Jonathan Maitland]] and starred [[Alistair McGowan]] as Savile.{{cite news |first=Lyn |last=Gardner |authorlink=Lyn Gardner |url= https://www.theguardian.com/stage/2015/jun/12/an-audience-with-jimmy-savile-review-alistair-mcgowan-is-repellently-convincing |title= An Audience with Jimmy Savile review – Alistair McGowan is repellently convincing |work= The Guardian |date= 12 June 2015|accessdate= 12 June 2015}} ==See also== {{portal|Crime|Sexuality|BBC|2010s}} * [[BBC controversies]] * [[Criticism of the BBC]] * [[Institutional abuse]] * [[Bill Cosby sexual assault cases]] * [[Harvey Weinstein sexual abuse allegations]] * [[Trial of Jian Ghomeshi]] * [[Weinstein effect]] ==References== {{reflist|30em}} ==Further reading== * {{cite book |last=[[Frank Furedi|Furedi, Frank]]|title=Moral Crusades in an Age of Mistrust|year=2013|publisher= Palgrave Macmillan|location= London|isbn=978-1-137-33801-3}} – "examines the sociological meaning of the sudden transformation of Jimmy Savile, the cultural icon, into the personification of evil" * {{cite book |last=Davies, Dan|title=In Plain Sight:The Life and Lies of Jimmy Savile|year=2014|publisher= Quercus|location= London|isbn=978-1-78206-743-6}} ==External links== ===Investigations=== * [http://www.nspcc.org.uk/news-and-views/our-news/child-protection-news/13-01-11-yewtree-report/yewtree-report-pdf_wdf93652.pdf ''Giving Victims a Voice''], joint report by the Metropolitan Police and NSPCC, published 11 January 2013 * [http://downloads.bbc.co.uk/bbctrust/assets/files/pdf/our_work/pollard_review/pollard_review.pdf The Pollard Review: Report], published 18 December 2012 * [http://www.bbc.co.uk/aboutthebbc/insidethebbc/howwework/reports/bbc_pollard_report_appendices_and_transcripts_2013.html#section-1 The Pollard Review: Appendices and Transcripts], published 22 February 2013 * [https://www.gov.uk/government/collections/nhs-and-department-of-health-investigations-into-jimmy-savile Reports of the NHS investigations into Jimmy Savile], published 26 June 2014 * {{redirects|niceness|the concept in general|pleasure}} [[File:Fifty-fifty - something better than rolling Easter eggs (cropped).jpg|thumb|upright+1.5|Two children sharing a [[soft drink]] at the [[White House]] in [[Washington, D.C.]], 1922, from the archives of the [[Library of Congress]]]] '''Kindness''' is a behavior marked by [[ethics|ethical]] characteristics, a pleasant [[disposition]], and concern and consideration for others. It is considered a [[virtue]], and is recognized as a [[Value (personal and cultural)|value]] in many cultures and religions (see [[ethics in religion]]).<ref>{{cite web |last=Khazan |first=Olga |url=https://www.theatlantic.com/business/archive/2015/06/it-pays-to-be-nice/396512/ |title=It Pays to Be Nice |publisher=[[The Atlantic]] |date=Jun 23, 2015 |accessdate=August 16, 2018 |deadurl=no}}</ref>
In Book II of "[[Rhetoric (Aristotle)|Rhetoric]]", Aristotle defines kindness as "helpfulness towards someone in need, not in return for anything, nor for the advantage of the helper himself, but for that of the person helped".<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.public.iastate.edu/~honeyl/Rhetoric/rhet2-7.html |title=Kindness |author=Aristotle (translated by Lee Honeycutt) |work=Rhetoric, book 2, chapter 7 |accessdate=2005-11-22 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20041213221951/http://www.public.iastate.edu/~honeyl/Rhetoric/rhet2-7.html |archivedate=December 13, 2004 }}</ref> [[Friedrich Nietzsche|Nietzsche]] considered kindness and love to be the "most curative herbs and agents in human intercourse".<ref>Nietzsche, Friedrich Wilhelm. "On the History of Moral Feelings," Human, all too human: a book for free spirits. Aphorism 48. [Original: Menschliches, Allzumenschiles, 1878.] Trans. Marion Faber with Stephen Lehman. University of Nebraska Press: First Printing, Bison Books, 1996.</ref> Kindness is considered to be one of the [[Knightly Virtues]].<ref>{{cite web|url=https://books.google.com.au/books?id=NnHHpCuox2IC&pg=PT20&lpg=PT20&dq=Kindness%20is%20considered%20to%20be%20one%20of%20the%20Knightly%20Virtues&source=bl&ots=NS9zXyFTUX&sig=-8H0ZlxWtVpFffgkNUXl7JBeGOM&hl=en&sa=X&ei=-8DiVPWxOuWwmwWtkIHADw&ved=0CCEQ6AEwAg|title=The Manual of Life - Character|publisher=Parvesh singla|via=Google Books}}</ref> In [[Meher Baba]]'s teachings, God is synonymous with kindness: "God is so kind that it is impossible to imagine His unbounded kindness!"<ref>Kalchuri, Bhau (1986). ''Meher Prabhu: Lord Meher'', '''11''', Myrtle Beach: Manifestation, Inc., p. 3918.</ref>
==In society== In human [[mating choice]], studies suggest that both men and women value kindness and intelligence in their prospective mates, along with physical appearance, attractiveness, social status, and age.<ref>Buss, David M., et al. "Sex differences in jealousy: Evolution, physiology, and psychology." Psychological science 3.4 (1992): 251-255</ref><ref>{{cite book|title=Psychology|first1= Henry |last1= Gleitman|first2=James |last2= Gross|first3=Daniel |last3= Reisberg|edition=8th}}</ref>
===Nice guy=== {{main|Nice guy}} A "nice guy" is an informal and usually stereotypical term for an (often young) adult male who portrays himself as gentle, compassionate, sensitive, and/or vulnerable.<ref name="McDaniel">{{cite journal |last=McDaniel |first=A. K. |year=2005 |title=Young Women's Dating Behavior: Why/Why Not Date a Nice Guy? |journal=Sex Roles |volume=53 |issue=5–6 |pages=347–359 |doi=10.1007/s11199-005-6758-z }}</ref> The term is used both positively and negatively.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://divalion.livejournal.com/163615.html |title=No More Mr. Nice Guy |first= |last=divalion |date=12 July 2005 |publisher= |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20130117015253/http://divalion.livejournal.com/163615.html |archivedate=17 January 2013 |df= }}</ref> When used positively, and particularly when used as a preference or description by someone else, it is intended to imply a male who puts the needs of others before his own, avoids confrontations, does favors, gives emotional support, tries to stay out of trouble, and generally acts nicely towards others.<ref>Glover, Dr. Robert, http://nomoremrniceguy.com</ref> In the context of a relationship, it may also refer to traits of honesty, loyalty, romanticism, courtesy and respect. When used negatively, a nice guy implies a male who is unassertive, does not express his true feelings and, in the context of dating (in which the term is often used<ref name="McDaniel" />), uses acts of [[Wiktionary:ostensible#English|ostensible]] friendship with the unstated aim of progressing to a romantic or sexual relationship.<ref>{{cite web | url=http://www.berkeleybeacon.com/opinion/2014/4/2/when-nice-guys-are-sexist-with-a-smile | title=When nice guys are sexist with a smile | publisher=Berkeley Beacon | date=2 April 2014 | accessdate=9 December 2014 | author=Blomquist, Daniel | deadurl=yes | archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20150320074725/http://www.berkeleybeacon.com/opinion/2014/4/2/when-nice-guys-are-sexist-with-a-smile | archivedate=20 March 2015 | df= }}</ref><ref name="maneater">{{cite web|last1=Dasgupta|first1=Rivu|title=The Friend Zone is Sexist|url=http://www.themaneater.com/stories/2014/2/13/friend-zone-sexist/|website=The Maneater|accessdate=1 November 2014}}</ref>
==In psychology== Based on experiments at Yale University using games with babies, some studies concluded that kindness is inherent to human beings.<ref>[https://www.nytimes.com/video/magazine/1247467772000/can-babies-tell-right-from-wrong-.html Can Babies Tell Right From Wrong?, Babies at Yale University's Infant Cognition Center respond to "naughty" and "nice" puppets., May 5, 2010]</ref> There are similar studies about the root of empathy in babies.<ref>[https://www.nytimes.com/1989/03/28/science/researchers-trace-empathy-s-roots-to-infancy.html?pagewanted=all Researchers Trace Empathy's Roots to Infancy, Daniel Goleman, 1989]</ref>
==In literature== * The ''[[Tirukkuṛaḷ]],'' an ancient [[Indian literature|Indian work]] on [[ethics]] and [[morality]], dedicates a separate chapter on kindness (Chapter 8, verses 71–80), furthering the value in other chapters, such as [[hospitality]] (verses 81–90), uttering pleasant words (verses 91–100), [[compassion]] (verses 241–250), [[vegetarianism]] (verses 251–260), [[non-violence]] (verses 311–320), [[non-killing]] (verses 321–330), and [[benignity]] (verses 571–580), among others.<ref>[http://ebooks.gutenberg.us/HimalayanAcademy/SacredHinduLiterature/weaver/content.htm Tirukkuṛaḷ]{{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20141216064046/http://ebooks.gutenberg.us/HimalayanAcademy/SacredHinduLiterature/weaver/content.htm |date=2014-12-16 }} verses 71-80</ref><ref>{{cite book |url=http://www.projectmadurai.org/pm_etexts/pdf/pm0153.pdf |title=Thirukkural English Translation and Commentary |publisher=W.H. Allen, & Co |first=GU |last=Pope <!--|authorlink=Thirukkural English Translation--> |year=1886 |pages=160}}</ref> * [[Mark Twain]] from a [[compassion]] point of view considered "Kindness [as a] language which the deaf can hear and the blind can see."<ref>{{cite book|author=Lorette M. Enochs|title=Seeds of Recovery: A Journal of 101 Mental Health Reflections|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=aFafDQAAQBAJ&pg=PT76|date=21 November 2016|publisher=AuthorHouse|isbn=978-1-5246-5181-7|page=76}}</ref> * It has been suggested that 'most of [[Shakespeare]]'s opus could be considered a study of human kindness'.<ref>Lagrette Tallent Lenker, ''Fathers and Daughters in Shakespeare and Shaw'' (2001) p. 107</ref> * [[Robert Louis Stevenson]] considered that 'the essence of love is kindness; and indeed it may best be defined as passionate kindness: kindness, so to speak, run mad and become importunate and violent'.<ref>robert Louis Stevenson, ''Virginibus Puerisque'' (London 1909) p. 35</ref> * The Christian apostle Paul lists kindness as one of the nine traits considered to be the "[[fruit of the Spirit]]" <ref>Galatians 5:22, New International Version</ref> in Galatians 5:22. In [[1_Corinthians_13#English_translation|1 Corinthians 13:4]] he states, "Love is patient, love is kind."<ref>1 Corinthians 13:4, New International Version</ref>
==In media== Based on the [[Pay It Forward (novel)|novel of the same name]] written in 1999 by author [[Catherine Ryan Hyde]], the motion picture [[Pay It Forward (film)|''Pay it Forward'']], which starred [[Kevin Spacey]], [[Helen Hunt]], [[Haley Joel Osment]] and [[Jon Bon Jovi]], illustrates the power one person can have to impact a chain reaction of kind deeds. The philosophy of Pay It Forward is that through acts of kindness among strangers, we all foster a more caring society. In the book and film, Reuben St. Clair, a [[social studies]] teacher in [[Atascadero, California]], challenges his students to "change the world". One of his students, Trevor, takes the challenge to heart. He starts by showing kindness to a stranger which ripples further than he could have ever imagined.
In October 2011, [[Life Vest Inside]] posted a video called "Kindness Boomerang".<ref name="Kindness Boomerang">{{cite web|url=https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=nwAYpLVyeFU|title=Kindness Boomerang|publisher=[[YouTube]]/Life Vest Inside|accessdate=14 January 2016}}</ref>It shows how one [[Random kindness|act of kindness]] passes seamlessly from one person to the next and boomerangs back to the person who set it into motion. Orly Wahba, Life Vest Inside Founder and Director of Kindness Boomerang explains that each scene was based on real life experiences she personally went through; moments of kindness that left a lasting impression on her life. Within several months after its release, Kindness Boomerang went viral; reaching over 20 million people globally and eventually landing Wahba spot on the TED2013<ref>[https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=yn9VxUPlC5g "TED Talk - Kindness - Orly Wahba"], ''YouTube/TED Conferences''. Retrieved January 14, 2016.</ref> stage to speak about the power of kindness.

{{more citations needed|date=May 2009}}
Listed below are '''the worst disasters in Poland's history''', listed '''by death toll'''. This list excludes warfare and intentional acts of destruction, but may include accidents in which the military, Polish or foreign, was involved (e.g. Osiecznica bus disaster - a collision between a Polish bus and a [[Northern Group of Forces|Soviet Army's]] truck).
Some of the disasters listed here occurred outside of current Polish borders (e.g. the [[2010 Polish Air Force Tu-154 crash|Smolensk Tu-154 crash]]) or in times when Poland was not internationally recognized (e.g. during the [[partitions of Poland]]), but the predominant number of victims were either Poles or Polish citizens.
== Over 100 confirmed deaths == * [[Renard coal mine disaster]], 1881, [[Sosnowiec]], around 200 killed * [[LOT Polish Airlines Flight 5055]], 1987 (9 May), [[Warsaw]], 183 killed * [[Kleofas coal mine disaster]], 1896, [[Katowice]] (then [[German Empire]]), 104 killed * [["Barbara-Wyzwolenie" coal mine disaster]], 1954 (21 March), [[Chorzów]], 103 killed
== 40 to 99 confirmed deaths == * [[2010 Polish Air Force Tu-154 crash|Smolensk Tu-154 crash]], 2010 (10 April), [[Smolensk]], (Russia), 96 killed, including Polish President [[Lech Kaczyński]], his wife and other political and military officials. * [[LOT Polish Airlines Flight 007]], 1980 (14 March), [[Warsaw]], 87 killed * [["Makoszowy" coal mine disaster]], 1958 (28 August), [[Zabrze]], 72 killed * [[Otłoczyn railway accident]], 1980 (19 August), near [[Brzoza Toruńska]], 67 killed * [[Katowice Trade Hall roof collapse]], 2006 (28 January), [[Chorzów]], 65 killed * [[Outdoor Cinema fire]], 1955 (11 May), [[Wielopole Skrzyńskie]], 58 killed * [[Górna Grupa mental hospital fire]], 1980 (31 October - 1 November), [[Górna Grupa]], 55 killed * [[Central European Flood]], 1997 (July), western Poland, 55 killed * [[MS Jan Heweliusz]], 1993 (14 January), [[Baltic Sea]] (near [[Rügen]] Island), 55 killed * [[LOT Polish Airlines Flight 165]], 1969 (2 April), [[Polica (mountain)|Polica]] (near [[Zawoja]]), 53 killed * [[1979 Warsaw gas explosion|Rotunda PKO Bank explosion]], 1979 (15 February), [[Warsaw]], 49 killed
== 20 to 39 confirmed deaths == * [[1978 Balkan Bulgarian Tupolev Tu-134 crash]], 1978 (16 March), Gabare ([[Bulgaria]]), 39 Poles killed (out of 73 total fatalities) * [[Czechowice-Dziedzice Refinery fire]], 1971 (26–27 June), [[Czechowice-Dziedzice]], 37 killed * [[1962 LOT Vickers Viscount Warsaw crash]], 1962 (19 December), [[Warsaw]], 33 killed * [[Poland bus disaster of 1994|PKS Gdańsk bus crash]], 1994 (2 May), [[Gdańsk]]-Kokoszki, 32 killed * [[Wilczy Jar buses tragedy]], 1978 (15 November), Wilczy Jar (n. [[Żywiec]]-Oczków), 30 killed * [[Accident on the Rampe de Laffrey (2007)|Grenoble coach crash]], 2007 (22 July), [[Vizille]] (France), 27 killed * [[Julianka rail crash]], 1976 (3 November), [[Julianka, Silesian Voivodeship|Julianka]] (n. [[Częstochowa]]), 25 killed * [[Osieck rail crash]], 1981 (4 June), [[Osieck]], 25 killed * [[MS Busko Zdrój]], 1985 (8 February), [[North Sea]], 24 killed * [[Kamień Pomorski homeless hostel fire]], 2009 (13 April), [[Kamień Pomorski]], 23 killed * [[Halemba coal mine disaster, 2006]], 2006 (22 November), [[Ruda Śląska]], 23 killed * [[MS Maria Konopnicka]] fire in [[Stocznia Gdańska]], 1961 (13 December), 23 killed * [[Wojska Polskiego 39 Street gas explosion]], 1995 (17 April), [[Gdańsk]], 22 killed * [[Mirosławiec air accident]] crash, 2008 (23 January), [[Mirosławiec]], 20 killed * [[MS Kudowa Zdrój]], 1983 (20 January), Mediterranean, 20 killed * [[Wujek-Śląsk coal mine disaster]], 18 September 2009, [[Ruda Śląska]]- a methane explosion killed 12 in the coal mine and a further 8 would die in hospital<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.trekearth.com/gallery/Europe/Poland/West/Slaskie/Laziska/photo1151123.htm |title=Coal mine story - The last relay Photo |publisher=TrekEarth |date= |accessdate=2010-05-24}}</ref>
== 15 to 19 confirmed deaths == * [[Balaton coach crash]], 2002 (1 July), n. [[Lake Balaton|Balaton]] (Hungary), 19 killed * [[Halemba coal mine disaster]], 1990 (10 January), [[Ruda Śląska]], 19 killed * [[Biały Jar avalanche]], 1968 (20 March), valley on [[Sněžka]] mountain (n. [[Karpacz]]), 19 killed * [[Nowe Miasto nad Pilica bus crash]], 2010 (12 October), [[Nowe Miasto nad Pilica]], 18 killed * "Mysłowice" coal mine disaster, 1987 (4 February), [[Mysłowice]], 18 killed * [[B406/6]] trawler explosion in [[Stocznia Gdańska]], 1980 (18 June), [[Gdańsk]], 18 killed * [[Motława ferry disaster|Motława]], 1975 (1 August), [[Gdańsk]], 18 killed * [[M/v "Nysa"]], 1965 (10 January), [[North Sea]], 18 killed * [[Polish Air Force]] [[An-24]] crash, 1973 (28 February), [[Szczecin]] airport 18 killed * [[Struga 12 street gas explosion]], 1976 (1 February), [[Gdańsk]], 17 killed * [[Szczekociny rail crash]], 2012 (3 March), [[Szczekociny]], killed 16 * [[Ursus rail crash]], 1990 (20 August), [[Ursus, Warsaw|Ursus]] (n. [[Warsaw]]), 16 killed * [[Radkowice rail crash]], 1973 (27 August), [[Radkowice]], 16 killed * [[Osiecznica bus crash]], 1978 (22 January), n. [[Osiecznica, Lubusz Voivodeship|Osiecznica]], 15 killed * [[Wyszaka streetcar crash]], 1967 (7 December), Szczecin, 15 killed
== 10 to 14 confirmed deaths == * [[Brandenburg coach crash]], 2010, (26 September), [[Schönefeld]] (Germany), 14 killed * [["Kaskada" restaurant fire]], 1981 (27 April), [[Szczecin]], 14 killed * [[MS Czubatka]], 1955 (10 May), [[North Sea]], 14 killed * [[Krosno Odrzańskie tornado]], 1886 (13 May), [[Krosno Odrzańskie]], 13 killed * [[Izbicko level crossing accident]], 1960, (6 January), [[Izbicko]], 13 killed * [[Storm in Mazury]], 2007 (21 August), [[Mazury]] (north-eastern Poland), 12 killed * [[Jeżewo coach crash]], 2005 (30 September), [[Sikory-Wojciechowięta]] (n. [[Wrocław]]), 11 killed (unofficial - 32 killed) * [["Jas-Mos" coal mine disaster]], 2002 (10 February), 10 killed * [[Ministry of Interior MSWiA helicopter crash]], 1991 (10 January), n. [[Cisna]], 10 killed * [[Drogomil level crossing accident]], 1988 (4 June), [[Drogomil]] (n. [[Bytom Odrzański]]), 10 killed * [[Piła rail crash]], 1988 (19 May), [[Piła]], 10 killed * [[MS Brda]], 1975 (10 January), [[Hanstholm]] (Denmark), 10 killed * [["Rokitnica" coal mine disaster]], 1971 (23 March), [[Zabrze]], 10 killed * [[Agricultural University building collapse]], 1966 (22 March), [[Wrocław]], 10 killed
== Fewer than 10 confirmed deaths == * [[Bratoszewice level crossing collision]], 2012 (30 July), 9 killed.<ref name=bbc19045735>{{cite news| url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/news/world-europe-19045735 | agency=[[Agence France-Presse]] (AFP) | publisher=BBC News | title=Nine killed as minibus and train collide in Poland | date=2012-07-30| accessdate = 2012-11-18}}</ref> * [[1983 Łódź gas explosion]], 1983 (7 December), [[Łódź]], 8 killed * [[2008 Poland tornado outbreak]], 2008 (15 to 16 August), 4 killed

{{Infobox civil conflict |title = Ludlow Massacre |image = Ruins of Ludlow restored.jpg |place = [[Ludlow, Colorado]] |date = April 20, 1914 |caption = Ruins of the Ludlow Colony in the aftermath of the massacre. | map_type = | map_caption = | map_size = | coordinates = {{coord|37|20|21|N|104|35|02|W|display=inline,title|type:event_scale:50000_region:US-CO}} | goals = # Recognition of the United Mine Workers of America (UMWA) in [[collective bargaining]]. # Compensation for digging coal at a ton-rate based on 2,000 pounds (Previous ton-rates were of long-tons of 2,200 pounds) # Enforcement of the eight-hour work-day law # Payment for "dead work" (laying track, timbering, handling impurities, etc.) # Weight-checkmen elected by workers. # Right to use any store, and to choose their boarding houses and doctors # Strict enforcement of Colorado's laws (such as mine safety rules, abolition of scrip), and an end to the company guard system | methods = [[Strike action|Strikes]], [[protest]], [[Demonstration (people)|demonstrations]] | status = | result = Large part of the Ludlow tent colony site destroyed by fire; UMWA organiser Louis Tikas assaulted and executed by gunshot (body is left for 3 days [[in situ]]); one bystander and five other males (including one 11-year-old boy) killed by gunshot; 2 women, 3 infants, and 8 children killed by suffocation and/or fires set by militiamen. News of event cause of worldwide protest and condemnation. | concessions = | side1= [[United Mine Workers of America]] (UMWA) | side2= [[Colorado Fuel and Iron|Colorado Fuel and Iron Company]];
[[Colorado National Guard]]
